title.narrative: Strengthen Conflict Prevention

description.narrative: How to Do Conflict prevention: An important aspect of this focus at the global level is the follow up of the recommendations from the 2015 UN review of peacekeeping operations, the peace architecture, the implementation of UN Security Council Resolution 1325 and the UN resolutions that followed, notably the so tion, continuation and recurrence of conflict, addressing root causes, assisting parties to conflict to end hostilities, ensuring national reconciliation, and moving towards - for the UN - a groundbreakingly new and expansive understanding, close to the idea of prevention. Sustaining peace is a political process that takes place before, during, and after the outbreak of conflict, and therefore also not the task of a single UN agency, but a system-wide responsibility.

title.narrative: Webinar on COVID-19, Peace and Human Security: Seeing the invisible and forgotten amidst the COVID-19 crisis.

description.narrative: 155 participants from the Philippines, Myanmar/Burma, Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, Singapore, and Bangladesh attended the webinar which focused on how the COVID-19 pandemic has created a global health challenge and exacerbated the pre-existing vulnerabilities of people living in communities with violence and political instability. Main questions discussed were: How are governments and/or ASEAN responding to the pandemic? What is the impact of the pandemic on conflict-affected, displaced and marginalized, and the response of community actors? What are the most critical tasks/roles for peacebuilders and human rights defenders working with conflict-affected, displaced and marginalized communities at this time?

title.narrative: Awareness raising on the dynamics of violent extremism through peace education

description.narrative: 20 schools and 60 teachers have been identified for the teaching of the PVE Manual in Burkina Faso, Mali, Niger and Nigeria. WANEP local offices in these countries identified and engaged with key stakeholders for the project implementation. These include Ministries of Education, Pedagogical Experts, Administrative Authorities, Schools Authorities, Teachers, Traditional Leaders etc. Advocacy activities were conducted in the 4 target countries with the aim of officially presenting the Preventing Violent Extremism project to relevant stakeholders and seeking their buy-in. These included: Ministries of Education and relevant departments and agencies, school authorities (Inspectors, Principals,etc.), Teachers and Communities and traditional leaders.

title.narrative: Rapid Needs and Capacities Assessment (RNCA) in relation to the COVID19 pandemic

description.narrative: A quick assessment was conducted with 25 national (Philippines: Davao provinces, Marawi and Lanao provinces, Cotabato, Magundanao, Bukidnon, Zamboanga provinces, and Metro Manila) and 9 regional (Malaysia/Sabah, Cambodia, Timor-Leste, Myanmar/Burma and Indonesia) partners after consultations with GPPAC-SEA and other networks. The objectives of the assessment were: 1. In the short-term, surface data to identify and respond to the needs of local and regional partners in light of the Covid-19 pandemic; and 2. In the medium to long-term, adjust the institution's and partners' strategies deemed fit in light of the Covid-19 outbreak. A Rapid Needs and Capacities Assessment was conducted from April-May 2020, was analysed and summarised in June and was circulated back to partners and respondents last 1 July 2020

title.narrative: Integrating the “Culture of good neighborhood” course in primary schools in Moldova (in Anenii Noi district and other locations)

description.narrative: A set of complementing activities have taken place comprising advocacy at various official events and public forums with teachers and parents, providing guidance on steps that may be taken to start applying the “Culture of good neighbourhood” optional course in a school curriculum; delivering a two 1-day seminars for new teachers, future implementers of the CGN course in Anenii Noi district of Moldova and for Gymnasium teachers, which included the local coordinators of the Ministry of Education, Research and Culture of Moldova from Anenii Noi; and developing a concept of video lessons for online teaching of the Culture of Good Neighbourhood subject in primary schools.

title.narrative: Youth from different factions and local authorities conduct joint peacebuilding and economic activity programmes in Burundi

description.narrative: A strong collaboration and peaceful co-existence have been enhanced among young people belonging to the different political parties and between young people and local authorities in the province of Makamba and the outlying districts of the capital Bujumbura in Burundi. The youth supporting different political parties who had been divided along ethnic lines and the local authorities now jointly conduct peacebuilding and economic activity programmes. The target groups are those at most affected and at most of the instability in the country. The intervention is important for the prevention of violence In Burundi – especially as the country heads towards election time when youth are always at the forefront of instability in the country. This is the first-time youth from different ethnic and political affiliations are working together and with the local authorities for a common goal of peace.

title.narrative: Between April-July 2019, three local Aggregated Territorial Communities (ATC) in the Chernivtsi region of Ukraine applied a model developed by GPPAC network members to work with conflicting historical memories.

description.narrative: Aggregated territorial communities are newly created basic units of local self-governance at the level of small towns or groups of villages in Ukraine. The Chernivtsi region is multi-ethnic but major communities are Romanian and Ukrainian, hence issues result from them being part of the same administrative unit. For Ukraine, historical issues are of great importance, both in the conflict in Eastern Ukraine and in local social conflicts elsewhere. These exhibitions are an important tool to help people recognise and understand these different perspectives.

title.narrative: For the first time, two ASEAN officials spoke out on the Rohingya issue, calling for regional action

description.narrative: An ASEAN joint statement dated 23 April 2018, by two ASEAN officials (permanent representatives of the ASEAN Intergovernmental Commission on Human Rights from Malaysia and Indonesia), called for “urgent action by ASEAN to develop a ‘whole-of-ASEAN approach’ in cooperation with Myanmar to deal more effectively with the human rights and refugee crises emerging in Rakhine State”. GPPAC-Southeast Asia members’ input was solicited in the drafting of the ASEAN joint statement. The GPPAC South-East Asia members’ statements (November 2017), and their recommendations and engagements (April 2018) calling for decisive action from the ASEAN on the crisis in Rakhine eventually contributed considerably to the ASEAN joint statement.

title.narrative: Civil monitoring mission to Southern Bessarabia to identify risks of escalation of tensions

description.narrative: An important decision made during the GPPAC Regional Steering Group meeting in June 2017 was to resume the practice of organising civil monitoring and assessment missions to areas of ongoing conflict and sites where there may be a risk of escalation of tensions (Early Warning Early Response). The first area for such a mission, selected during the regional network meeting, was Southern Bessarabia – an area in the west Odessa region, with a multi-ethnic population that is relatively isolated from other parts of Ukraine. The mission took place in October 2017 and a mission report including follow-up actions is currently being finalised.

title.narrative: Training on Resilience and Dialogue in times of crisis

description.narrative: As a result of GPPAC Western Balkans first online training on Resilience and Dialogue in the Times of Crisis, 20 teachers and peace educators from Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro and Croatia improved their personal and professional capacities to develop resilience and dialogue skills in order to support colleagues, students and parents in crisis situations with a particular focus on the current health crisis. The teachers were equipped with practical skills on how to build resilience among students and inspire colleagues and parents to do the same.

description.narrative: As part of its work advocating for increased space for civil society within the UN process, GPPAC Gender Focal Points and representatives from the YPS WG attended several events with the objective of putting conflict prevention with women’s participation and gender analysis at the core of the action. It included conversations with the Permanent Mission of Germany and Canada, the EU delegation and UN Women. Conversations with UN Women around GPPAC providing input to the UN reviews and upcoming publications on WPS and YPS.

title.narrative: Online High-Level Expert Meeting and policy brief on ''The importance of including young men and women in building sustainable peace in Libya''

description.narrative: As part of the SDG16+ in light of COVID activity, the Coordinator of the WG and GPPAC's UN Liaison supported GPPAC member in Egypt and GPPAC member-to-be in Libya to host an online High-Level Expert Meeting on 5 November on ''The importance of including young men and women in building sustainable peace in Libya.'' Mr. Rawhi Afaghani from UNDP Conflict Prevention and Peacebuilding was a speaker as well as Mr. Abdulrhman Almahdi from the Libyan Authority for Youth and Sport. The availability of Arabic-English interpretation enabled many local peacebuilders to actively take part in the conversation and shape recommendations for the UN. There were more than 50 participants, including from civil society and UN offices. As a result of the meeting, GPPAC collected recommendations brought forward by various actors in a policy brief titled ''Agents and Drivers of Peace in Libya'' (published 11 December on GPPAC website)

Furthermore, the National Association of Mediators of Ukraine (NAMU) has included gender sensitivity as one of the topics of training programs for practicing mediators.

title.narrative: Social cohesion training among youth in post-election communities in Burundi

description.narrative: Burundian population is characterized by a lack of livelihoods, exposure of communities to manipulation (by political actors) and social injustices in an environment of indifference and devoid of mechanisms of community solidarity. GPPAC member Biraturaba has set up community mechanisms for economic and social resilience. These are community groups of solidarity, savings and credit, and at the same time serve as a framework for exchange, conflict management, mutual aid and economic recovery. These groups bring together people of different ethnicities and political tendencies by giving them the opportunity to see the strength they constitute when they go beyond what opposes them.However, networks do not have enough knowledge to become more involved and to control potential conflicts long before they emerge – thus the training aims to answer these shortcomings.

title.narrative: Restoration of trust and confidence in central Burundi

description.narrative: By December 2019, the collaboration between communities, CSOs and administrative authorities in responding to conflicts and building peace has improved significantly in Bisoro community, Mwaro province, in central Burundi. This has restored trust and confidence and paved the way for joint peace actions and improvement in the livelihoods of 800 community members in Bisoro community. The indirect beneficiaries are between 3200 and 3,500 people, who are the households of the 800 community members. The intervention focused on improving household economic empowerment and peace (with a focus on women).

title.narrative: Youth peace champions in Uganda

description.narrative: By December 2020, 270 young adults in 3 districts (Kaabong, Kotido and Lira) in Uganda who were ring-leaders of violence like armed cattle rustling in their communities had declared themselves peace champions and reached out to 4600 peers to convince them to abandon violent acts and embrace peace - in a period of 8 months. For example, in Kaabong and Kotido, districts, 65 warriors were convinced to abandon the bush, join the peace champions groups and are now also leading in community sensitizations towards peacebuilding and youth livelihood activities - with testimonies like "I used to lead my fellows into raiding. I am now leading in teaching my fellows into making hand-craft shoes in which they can get income" - a former warrior in Kotido district. The outcome is significant because it is a key proactive response to prevent the high threats of the target groups re-arming themselves and causing the re-emergence of violence. For example, there are high chances for the now disarmed (by government) youth in Kaabong and Kotido districts who used to view a gun as a source of livelihood, to re-arm themselves if nothing is done to support them. Furthermore, youth such as those formerly abducted by the rebels, born in captivity and former child soldiers are vulnerable to sliding into violence if not engaged positively.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: 1.2.2. Civil society reach out to key conflict/prevention stakeholders to engage them in developing inclusive prevention and protection strategies

title.narrative: Around 100 youth became ‘peace champions’ to prevent youth re-radicalisation in post-conflict Uganda

description.narrative: By February 2020, 2278 youth and young adults in 3 post-conflict districts (Kaabong, Yumbe and Kasese) in Uganda had abandoned acts of violence and embraced peacebuilding and income-generating activities as a means of preventing youth re-radicalization and slide back into armed violence – including 25 former combatants who abandoned gun-violence, and handed over guns to government authorities. The youth and young adults were sensitized and convinced by their peers referred to as peace champions (94 - 37 female and 57 male), who had been perpetrators of violent acts like armed cattle rustling, and rebel activity-related acts against the government of Uganda but declared themselves peace champions and started luring their peers into peacebuilding and income-generating activities.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: The networks and network members build support for conflict prevention by engaging with and building capacities of key stakeholders

title.narrative: Community leaders in Karamoja region work together in educating community members to embrace gender justice in Uganda

description.narrative: By February 2020, women leaders at the community level (district, sub-county level and village level) in the Districts of Kaabong, Moroto and Amudat in Karamoja region – a region known for high levels of negative cultural practices, have transformed their minds and also transformed the minds of men towards women and embraced gender justice. Women leaders and male counterparts at community level who used to support violent acts against women like female genital mutilation, lack of property rights, wife-beating, no participation of women in important decision making processes, not contesting for open (not under affirmative action) leadership positions, wife inheritance, etc as normal are now working together and leading in educating community members to embrace gender justice. The sensitisation efforts are done through community advocacy clubs, community talking circles and dance and drama.

description.narrative: The networks and network members build support for conflict prevention by engaging with and building capacities of key stakeholders

title.narrative: Dialogue-Roundtable between civil society and Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) through ASEAN civil society Conference and -People’s Forum

description.narrative: CSO advocacy by 5 GPPAC members at the ASEAN Civil Society Conference/ ASEAN People’s Forum (ACSC/APF) 2018 (2-4 November 2018) held in Singapore, and on “Empowering People’s Solidarity Against All Forms of Discrimination”. The forum was designed to be a conversation among representatives of ASEAN particularly the ASEAN Institute for Peace and Reconciliation (AIPR), ASEAN Inter-governmental Commission on Human Rights (AICHR) and ASEAN Commission on the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Women and Children (ACWC), and representatives from the Rohingya community and groups working for peace and humanitarian situation in Rakhine state in Burma on the current responses of the ASEAN and prospects for substantial and effective collaboration with civil society, solidarity movements and advocacy groups on the Rohingya issue. Core advocacy messages were based on the submission by the participants to the dialogue on the Rohingya situation in the ASEAN agreed during the dialogue activity became part of the official statement of the whole ACSC/APF2018 conference.

title.narrative: 1.3. Improving policy (DD3)

description.narrative: 1.3.3. Intergovernmental and state actors demonstrate readiness to consider civil society - including women and youth - input in official negotiation process

title.narrative: International round table "From cyber to fake. Hybrid power languages in the Black Sea”.

description.narrative: Competition for power at the regional level has intensified in the Wider Black Sea region, with direct disruptive effects on the region's security and stability. This competition is expressed through a various geopolitical languages of its actors (political, diplomatic, military, economic, ideological), in a diverse, hybrid and sophisticated manner, from predominantly military languages (maritime exercises, new military design, trends to rebuilding the military architecture) to predominantly ideological languages (historical revisionism, disinformation campaigns, information war), from cyber to fake, from frigates to fictions. Experts in the region have often discussed the effects of these languages, omitting / ignoring or underestimating its nature, which explains the real intentions of the state and non-state actors in the region. The round-table analyzed the nature and collisions of these languages in order to prevent further deterioration of the regional security situation. It took place on 29 June, 2020, and was attended by 16 top experts from 6 countries: Belarus, Georgia, Romania, Moldova, Turkey, and Ukraine. This event was organized by the Black Sea House Association, in partnership with the European Democratic Culture Initiative / ICDE Association, Bucharest and Constanta branch (Romania) and the Institute for World Politics (Kyiv, Ukraine) with the assistance of members of EE GPPAC.

title.narrative: 1.1 Civil society capacity

description.narrative: 1.1.1. Network members engage in regional and cross-regional exchanges, working groups and action research on priority themes

title.narrative: County Government Watch (CGW) held interventions in eight of the nineteen counties in Kenya leading to less violence around the elections

description.narrative: County Government Watch (CGW) from Kenya was supported by GPPAC. CGW is collaborating with Saferworld in conducting county-based multi-stakeholder forums aimed at bringing together relevant stakeholders to chart the way forward in relation to the General Elections in Kenya in 2017. The platforms were/are an opportunity for different stakeholders to come together and review strategies and mechanisms put in place to ensure that the elections were free, fair and credible. The interventions were/are county specific, which led to a national stakeholders’ forum that reviewed actions and measures taken by various stakeholders to ensure peaceful elections. Eight of the nineteen counties were covered by CGW interventions and initial feedback learned that there was less violence in these counties, most likely due to the round table and related events organised by CGW.

title.narrative: DD4 - 1.4 - Acting on policies and operationalising norms

description.narrative: 1.4.3. Intergovernmental, state actors and non-state actors take steps to act on early warnings and apply prevention and protection norms and principles in practice

title.narrative: Caucasus Networks of journalists, CSOs and media enabled to communicate effectively on conflict prevention

description.narrative: Despite tensions, Armenian, Georgian and Azerbaijani journalists and civil society agreed to work together more closely on conflict prevention. During 4th quarter of 2018 GPPAC organised a training on Human Security Essentials based on GPPAC Handbook on Human Security for 10 women community leaders residing in the villages adjacent to the conflict zone. Nine freelance and peace journalists selected by GPPAC South Caucasus and its partner CSOs in Georgia, Azerbaijan and Armenia produced 10 articles on peace, conflict prevention and confidence building and underlined GPPAC experience in this area. Creating the ground for a network of GPPAC freelance press officers in the region. Georgian, Armenian and Azerbaijani journalists improved their knowledge about ways and methods of detecting and fighting hate speech on social media and in traditional media. Azerbaijani and Armenian CSOs and journalists have become more tolerable towards different points of view on the conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh and expressed readiness to cooperate.

title.narrative: Implementing educational course “Culture of good neighborhood” in Moldova and Transnistria

description.narrative: During 4th quarter of 2018 GPPAC members contribute to further development of school education on living together peacefully in post-conflict communities in Moldova and Transnistria. CSOs and local partners developed and implemented the educational course “Culture of good neighborhood” / “Living in peace and harmony” for elementary schools with relevant educational courses in middle school level. Holding a second seminar for new teachers who teach the optional subject ”Culture of good neighborhood” in TL ”A. Pușkin”, in Chisinau on 29 October with 17 participants. Monitoring the process of teaching the “Culture of good neighborhood” course in new schools.

title.narrative: Peace education becomes part of official curriculum in Moldovan region

description.narrative: During May-June 2020, the educational authorities in the Anenii-Noi district of Moldova agreed to start implementing the “Culture of Good Neighborhood” educational course in most elementary schools of the district starting September 2020. GPPAC members were able to persuade the district education department in the Anenil-Noi to encourage the integration of the Culture of Good Neighborhood” course in most schools of that district. 17 schools (29 teachers+653 children) are expected to start applying for the proposed educational course starting September 2020.

title.narrative: 1.3 Improving policy

description.narrative: 1.3.2. Intergovernmental and state actors incorporate inclusive prevention and protection principles in their relevant policies

title.narrative: Moldovan children increased their willingness to engage in dialogue and resolve conflict situations

description.narrative: During November-December 2020, we evaluated the implementation of the optional discipline "Culture of good neighbourhood" in schools of The Republic of Moldova and the Transnistria region which involved 313 students and 6 teachers. Results of evaluation demonstrate that the course "Culture of good neighbourhood" formed certain competences in students of primary classes. Based on the answers obtained in course of the study, children have responsible attitude towards those next to them; willingness to engage in dialogue, negotiate and resolve conflict situations; capitalizing on the principles of a culture of peace and of intercultural and multilingual education; active involvement and manifestation of a personal position towards the history and culture of the country and the ability to generate new, constructive ideas.

title.narrative: On 12 May 2019 for the first time GPPAC staff provided Lobby and Advocacy Workshop in Yaoundé, Cameroon

description.narrative: During a 3-day validation workshop on the Voluntary National Review of UN SDG16 on Peace Justice and Inclusive Institutions, GPPAC staff provided a workshop on Lobby and Advocacy to 30 participants from different civil society organisations coming from different regions in Cameroon. The participants acknowledged that the workshop was necessary for the peacebuilding field. For GPPAC member, Women in Alternative Action (WAA) this was needed for the phase of implementation of the key recommendations that come out of the Country Report Progress towards peaceful, just and inclusive societies: SDG 16+ in Cameroon, published in June 2019. There were several significant opportunities where WAA Cameroon could apply these advocacy and lobby capacities, such as at the UN High Level Political Forum in New York in July 2019 and during the bilateral engagements with permanent missions of several countries (Switzerland, Germany, The EU Delegation and others) to the UN.

title.narrative: 1.1 Civil society capacity. 1.1.2: Network members collaborate to gather and develop civil society resources and expertise on norms and approaches (DD5)
GPPAC members from Georgia, Azerbaijan and Armenia agree to advance the implementation of SDG 16 during a Human Security workshop on 9-10 April 2019.

description.narrative: During a two-day workshop on Human Security, GPPAC members from Georgia, Azerbaijan and Armenia, peace journalists and experts discussed human security issues within the regional context, and their country-specific challenges. They developed recommendations for promoting the conflict prevention toolbox as part of the implementation of SDG 16. In addition, they agreed that future policy papers should focus on the implementation of SDG 16.

title.narrative: Participating organisations in the ‘Voices for SDG 16+’ campaign, which GPPAC helped form as one of its earliest partners, moved from autonomous, single advocacy as individual organisations towards joint advocacy messages and joint advocacy events to argue for greater focus on further local implementation of SDG 16+ on 24 July 2019.

description.narrative: During the High Level Political Forum in New York, SDG16 received greater attention as 11 organisations coalesced around the campaign, agreeing to pool resources and develop a joint advocacy messages and events. This is an important qualitative shift in the way policy and implementing organisations have been working thus far.

title.narrative: On 13 March 2019, in the speech of the UN Women Executive Director during the Commission on the Status of Women 63, the role of young people and meaningful contribution of young women was highlighted, recognised and legitimised. Participation of the co-chair of the GPPAC Youth, Peace, and Security Working Group in this where there were few youth represented, contributed to the visibility of young women there.

description.narrative: During the event Intergenerational Dialogue "Take the Hot Seat" organised by UN Women, UN Secretary General's Envoy on Youth, Girls Scouts and the Working Group on Girls at the CSW63, the UN Women Executive Director, Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, stressed the role of youth in leading the way forward in implementing the Beijing Platform for Action: “When we celebrate 25 years [of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action], my commitment to you is that you will be there. You will speak for yourselves. You will tell us what you want and the future you want.” There were not many young people in the age range of 18-29 present at CSW63. Eliska Jelinkova, co-chair of the GPPAC Youth, Peace, and Security Working Group, was one of the few. Her participation in the CSW63 and presentation, as well as participation in various side events contributed to the visibility of young women in the discussion on Women, Peace, and Security.

title.narrative: Improving Practice Working Group Training of Trainers in Beijing, PR China and Exchange and Learning Visit GPPAC – KNPC in Pyongyang, North Korea

description.narrative: Experts in conflict prevention and peacebuilding who are part of the GPPAC network joined an ‘Improving Practice Working Group’ delegation for learning, exchange and training in Northeast Asia. The members offered a multistakeholder processes workshop to the Charhar Institute in Beijing and a conflict analysis workshop to North Korean members and partners, in addition to sharing peacebuilding experiences from different parts of the world. During the stay in Pyongyang, working group experts led a workshop on Conflict Analysis for members of KNPC and five other local organisations. The first of its kind to be held in Pyongyang, the workshop was based on GPPAC’s conflict analysis field guide.

Creative Associations and Fhi360 mentioned that they are interested in funding the local CSO directly and would like to hear from GPPAC members.

title.narrative: GPPAC’s Regional Secretariat for West Africa, West Africa Network for Peacebuilding (WANEP), is the first peacebuilding civil society organisation to be invited by the Government of Ghana to participate in the national coalition of CSOs on SDG 16+ on July 2019

description.narrative: Following the presentation of the SDG 16+ review on Ghana in New York, WANEP was invited by the Government of Ghana in July 2019 to participate in the national coalition of CSOs on SDG 16+ working with the government on SDG planning and implementation/review. The coalition had until then lacked representation of peacebuilding CSO’s.

title.narrative: 1.3. Improving policy and adopting recommendations

title.narrative: Formation of a transitional government of national unity in South Sudan

description.narrative: Following the recent armed conflict in South Sudan that led to the signing of the revitalized peace agreement in 2018, President Salva Kiir and opposition leader Riek Machar, finally fulfilled one of the key peace agreement issues and formed a transitional government of national Unity in March 2020 as a means of restoring peace in South Sudan. GPPAC contributed to the outcome by holding in 2019 a national meeting on the Development of recommendations for the implementation of the peace deal. The activity attracted several high level and key influential actors. After the meeting, GPPAC member CEPO continued to make several follow-up meetings and engagements towards ensuring that the recommendations in the peace agreement were fulfilled.

title.narrative: 1.4. Acting on policies and operationalising norms

description.narrative: Governments and intergovernmental institutions take steps to act on policies and operationalise norms and frameworks for conflict prevention and the protection of people and collaborate with civil society

title.narrative: Preventing electoral-related violence among youth in Somalia

description.narrative: From 1-30 December 2020, GPPAC partner organised several activities aimed at countering/preventing election violence in Somalia in which elections are projected to take place early 2021. The project targeted Youth, Media, Women and Political elites to ensure maintaining social harmony before, during and after election. This was achieved through rebuffing false information, incitement and instilling a sense of unity, patriotism and citizenship. The activities of the project included a 2-3 minute awareness message video and a 30 minute TV program where experts discuss preventing election violence in detail.

title.narrative: Training of Insider Youth Mediators

description.narrative: From 25th -29th November 2019, in Mathare and Kawangware Slums, Nairobi, Kenya. A highly interactive and participatory training focused on the following skills: conflict analysis, negotiation and mediation strategies, problem solving and communication skills, analysis of grievances, key actors, key mobilizers, institutions for peace and conflict, and social patterns of conflict in Kawangware and Mathare informal settlements and, simulated small groups mediation on various types of conflicts in these neighborhoods. Such conflicts include Youth-police conflicts, tenants-slumlords conflicts, inter-ethnic political conflicts, communities- criminal gangs conflicts among others.

title.narrative: Mainstreaming SDGs at the district level in Uganda

description.narrative: From September 2020, Kaabong District Local Government has mainstreamed SDGs into their district planning process. This follows the SDG localization meeting with key actors in Kaabong district in which the district took an action point to mainstream SDGs in their planning and development planning process. SDGs are now used as one of the key checklists for planning and review of local government plans right from village, parish, sub county and district level.

title.narrative: Office of the Prime Minister in Uganda adopts CSO recommendations on SDGs.

description.narrative: From September 2020, the SDG Secretariat in the Office of the Prime Minister has accepted and is in the process of putting in place several key recommendations highlighted in the SDG16+ study – especially in regard to enhancing SDG localization and SDG data and coordination. Following the study activities and sharing, the SDG secretariat requested GPPAC-CECORE to engage stakeholders in Kaabong district to discuss and agree on SDG Focal persons at district level as a way of enhancing SDG data and bridging the coordination gap with the national level.

title.narrative: Regional civil rapid reaction platform created for preventing violence during elections in Chernivtsy region in Ukraine

description.narrative: GPPAC Eastern European Network sent missions to areas of potential conflict and organized a regional civil rapid reaction platform for the prevention of electoral violence or escalation of tensions, during the electoral period in Ukraine in Chernivtsy region. The platform was created during a round-table on the risks of electoral violence in the region, by relevant experts and civil society representatives on December 21, 2018, and was followed by a program on local TV.

title.narrative: Confidence building among women by GPPAC Focal Point for Brazzaville, Congo, inspires Congolese women to fight for their rights in April 2019.

description.narrative: GPPAC Focal Point for Brazzaville, Congo, raised awareness among women in the country on their Human Rights. One of the key steps the GPPAC focal point and women embarked on is monitoring of police violence against women. This activity helped to raise awareness among Congolese public opinion about violence committed by Congolese law enforcement agents. Several women decided to file complaints for the murders caused by police in the Pointe Noire region. Some policemen were sentenced to several sentences following these complaints in April 2019.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection

title.narrative: For the first time, five Georgian state agencies showed responsiveness to GPPAC’s Georgian, Armenian and Azerbaijani civil society members by participating in a questionnaire targeted at state agencies about conflict prevention and their practices (April-June 2019).

description.narrative: GPPAC Georgian, Armenian and Azerbaijani CSOs and experts developed a questionnaire about conflict prevention based on best international practices for state agencies in charge of conflict management and prevention. The questionnaire was contextualised with the realities of each participant country. GPPAC Regional Secretariat for the South Caucuses, International Centre of Conflict and Negotiation (ICCN) sent the questionnaire to the Prime Minister’s Office and its department in charge of the UN Sustainable Development Agenda 2030, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Internal Affairs, Ministry of Defence, State Security Service and the State Minister’s Office for Reconciliation and Civil Integration. ICCN received responses from all the agencies and analysed them together with experts and CSOs. The responses and the information gathered were used to further GPPAC members’ work on the Conflict Prevention toolbox.

title.narrative: 1.3. Improving policy and adopting recommendations

description.narrative: Intergovernmental and state actors incorporate people-centred inclusive prevention and protection norms and principles in their policies and decision making processes

title.narrative: Functioning of six global Working Groups of CSOs to exchange expertise for lobby & advocacy on conflict prevention

description.narrative: GPPAC Global Secretariat has set up 4 global Working Groups in 2017 on (1) Improving Practice, (2) Policy & Advocacy, (3) Enabling Collaboration, and (4) Prevention of Violent Extremism (PVE). The working groups had online meetings and the Working Group Improving Practice met physically in The Hague, focusing on exchange of experience around using GPPAC’s training curriculum handbook on Human Security and Security Sector Reform, and how to take this further. The global working group of Gender Focal Points is the fifth global Working Group of GPPAC. They met during the Gender week in October 2017 and engaged with various UN bodies to advocate for inclusivity in peacebuilding processes. Local follow-up by members with UN DPA country desk officers was reported from Pacific/Fiji, Cameroon and Sri Lanka. The 6th global Working Group on Peace Education met in December 2017 in Armenia, organised by GPPAC member “Women for Development” from Armenia during the International Conference “Peace Education for Peacebuilding”. The Working Group members advocated the international community towards peacebuilding and the necessity of spreading the culture of peace among the young generation.

description.narrative: GPPAC PEWG experts, representing 12 world regions, offered three online courses of 6 weeks on "Conflict Resolution Education and Peace Education and Technology”, “Core Skills of Conflict Resolution and Peacebuilding”, and “Conflict Resolution and Peacebuilding as a Classroom Management Tool”.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

title.narrative: In April 2019, 9 groups of young adults in 3 districts (Kaabong, Yumbe and Kasese) in Uganda who were perpetrators of violence in their communities declared themselves as peace champions and started leading their peers into peacebuilding and income generating activities in their communities.

description.narrative: GPPAC Regional Secretariat for Eastern and Central Africa, Center for Conflict Resolution (CECORE), in partnership with GPPAC are implementing a project on “Building peace through young adult peace champions in post conflict communities in Uganda”. The project is aimed at preventing re-radicalization in selected post-conflict communities in Uganda in a bid to prevent the targeted young adults from sliding back into acts of violence. The participating 94 young adults (37 female and 57 male) had been ring-leaders in violent acts like armed cattle rustling, and rebel activity-related acts against the government of Uganda. For example, in Kasese, the young adults are now conducting joint community awareness with heads of security in the district (Resident District Commissioner) to create community awareness on peace and income generation.

title.narrative: Validation workshop held on Voluntary National Review on UN SDG 16+ & peace justice and inclusive institutions in Cameroon

description.narrative: GPPAC and GPPAC member WAA Cameroon conducted a civil society review of progress in the country towards SDG16+. A validation workshop was held for key stakeholders to discuss its implementation and present the key findings and recommendations of the research. The report was presented during the High-Level Forum on SDGs in New York in July 2019. WAA and CECORE have also produced videos on SDG16+ that were showcased during the High-Level Forum. With such support, the national Focal Point for Cameroon affirms “GPPAC has been very instrumental in promoting peace in Cameroon”.

title.narrative: GPPAC facilitates a dialogue of CSOs, UN and States to implement the Sustaining Peace Agenda

description.narrative: GPPAC co-facilitates an experts-level dialogue between civil society, UN agencies and Member States to discuss how best to advance the Sustaining Peace Agenda in order to deliver on its promises. The first meeting was held in December 2018 and continues in 2019. The UN Peacebuilding Support Office invited GPPAC and its partners to help design this process of meetings including to uptake CSOs recommendations.

Dutch MFA, DFID, Canada and South Korea).

title.narrative: Building stronger peacebuilding movement

description.narrative: GPPAC continues to align objectives and strengthen joint action of peacebuilding actors within civil society; thereby, strengthening the peacebuilding movement around common objectives. In addition to maintaining its convening platforms (sustaining peace roundtable series and the CS-UN Prevention Platform), GPPAC has worked to mobilize joint action with DHF and LPI around the SIPRI Forum and the PBC COVID convening. The NYPG that has been previously inactive has moved to host four policy dialogues: with PBSO and the Eminent Panel for the 2020 Review under the leadership of GPPAC (increased the recognition of the NYPG as a group for PBSO) and the co-facilitators of the 2020 Review (leed by GNWP). GPPAC has also brought additional capacities on board with the NYPG that helped mobilise the activities within the group. Together with LPI, GPPAC has also convened the 2020 Review civil society working group to mobilize the joint action for stronger implementation in the post-2020 phase, which concluded with the civil society reflection session, where the LPI-GPPAC coordination has been recognized as a good practice.

description.narrative: GPPAC has developed the UN Advocacy Toolkit that includes an overview of the UN and its Agendas, GPPAC's advocacy at the UN, and how GPPAC Members can bring their messages to New York The Advocacy Toolkit includes a section on the Women, Peace and Security, as well as discusses the key actors that are relevant in advocacy on women, peace and security. In October 2019 an advocacy training for gender focal points was conducted using the toolkit.

title.narrative: Roundtable discussions on Pathways for Peace Report and Youth to improve the operationalisation of the Sustaining Peace Agenda

description.narrative: GPPAC in collaboration with the International Peace Institute, the Dag Hammarskjold Foundation and the Global Network of Women Peacebuilders, hosted 2 discussions on 30 January and 1 March 2019 as part of a series of roundtables on sustaining peace. These sessions brought together UN staff, Member States and CSOs to advance the implementation of the sustaining peace agenda by discussing challenges and brainstorming collectively on how to move forward. Each session featured a speaker GPPAC provided from the field who gave practical examples of challenges and successes.

title.narrative: In July 2019, Executive director of the NGO Working Group on Women Peace and Security invited GPPAC to become part of the organisational committee of the second Multistakeholder Forum on Women, Peace and Security (WPS) that will take place on 28 October 2019 due to GPPAC being seen as a relevant actor to shape the Multistakeholder Forum.

description.narrative: GPPAC is an active member of the NGO Working Group on Women Peace and Security since February 2018 by contributing thematically to knowledge products and providing input for various processes. A delegation of GPPAC members has been participating in the Women, Peace and Security activities at UN New York level annually since 2010. GPPAC’s track record on the WPS agenda lead to the NGO Working Group on Women Peace and Security inviting GPPAC to be an active partner in the formulation of the agenda, format, participants and facilitators for the second Multistakeholder Forum on WPS. The event will be held in collaboration with NGO Working Group Sweden and UN Women.

title.narrative: Operationalizing conflict prevention and civil peacebuilding practices in Eastern Europe

description.narrative: GPPAC members in Eastern Europe continued the analysis of experiences of organizing civil dialogue across “lines of contact”, assessment of their potential “transferability” and preparation of a publication on these issues, complying materials about the experience of civil society organizations that address conflicts related to conflicting historical narratives and attitudes toward various historical figures or events. An online seminar “Historical memories and the search for civil consent” was held on November 24, 2020. It allowed us to discuss the practices of working with this topic in different countries of the region (Ukraine, Belarus, Moldova, Romania and Russia). Members of the network, together with representatives of other NGOs from Ukraine, Belarus, Moldova and Romania, became involved in a discussion regarding civil society approaches in addressing conflicts that are related to different attitudes toward various historical events and figures. We also launched the publication “CIVIL SOCIETY EXPERIENCES IN WORKING WITH CONFLICTS RELATED TO DIFFERENT ATTITUDES TOWARD HISTORICAL ISSUES AND FIGURES”

title.narrative: GPPAC is expanding and consolidating its alliance building and advocacy work around the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)

description.narrative: GPPAC participated in and hosted a workshop on challenges and strategies to implement SDG 16 during the SDG Global Festival of Action organised by the UN SDG Action campaign in Bonn on 21-22 March 2018. This led to an agreement on continued exchanges and work between like-minded CSOs around SDG 16. As such, GPPAC has established itself within an international forum as one of the main CSOs working on conflict prevention and peacebuilding that are active on the SDGs.

title.narrative: Capacity building on Conflict Transformation and Peace Journalism in Cambodia.

description.narrative: GPPAC provided media practitioners with a better understanding of peace and conflict theory, causes of conflict, conflict analysis, conflict intervention, communication, stress management, way to write peaceful media, war and peace journalism, journalist Code of Ethics, through presentation, participatory approaches, group discussions and exercises. It was aimed to encourage and capacitate media practitioners to assist in curbing hate speech and discrimination in the time of COVID19 and political repression in Cambodia.

description.narrative: GPPAC started developing a project titled "Financing for Peacebuilding: Building Opportunities for Local Civil Society" in partnership with DHF. The project aims to develop strategies for increasing the availability of funds to local civil society and their networks. The UN Liaison supported the development of the WPS and Humanitarian Compact for the Beijing 25+ process by providing recommendations on how the Compact could be financed in a way that meaningfully supports its work and integrates civil society perspectives in this work.

title.narrative: Workshop Outcome Harvesting to improve the quality of OH Practices among Strategic Partnerships

description.narrative: GPPAC took the initiative to find co-financing for improving practices in Outcome Harvesting. GPPAC started practicing Outcome Harvesting already in 2009 and currently there are at least half of the 25 Strategic Partnership Alliances (or within the NGOs of SP Alliances) that also started practicing Outcome Harvesting for their Monitoring & Evaluation system. GPPAC managed get financial support from the Knowledge Management Fund of the Secretariat of the Knowledge Platform Security and Rule of Law to organise two expert workshop and develop guidance to improve the quality of Outcome Harvesting Practices among the Strategic Partnerships. The first workshop - a training for 20 NGO representatives - took place in December 2017.

title.narrative: GPPAC presented at Partos Strategic Partnerships Meet Up on the new roles and partnerships in international advocacy

description.narrative: GPPAC was invited to propose a presentation for the Partos Strategic Partnerships Meetup ‘New roles and partnerships in international advocacy’, and was one of three partnerships selected to present. Charlotte Crockett presented on the functioning of the GPPAC network, and what it really means to be ‘member-led’. The audience in large part consisted of more traditional development organizations, many of whom are looking for ways to shift power in their relationships with Southern partners, away from partners being mere implementers of Dutch development organisations’ plans. There was a lot of interest in GPPAC’s approach, as well as that of the ‘Count Me In’ Strategic Partnership led by Mama Cash.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection

title.narrative: Mobilizing peacebuilding response to the COVID pandemic

description.narrative: GPPAC worked to mobilise support for the early peacebuilding response to the COVID-19 pandemic by engaging with the UN actors at the field levels (Peace and Development Adviisors), mobilizing Peacebuilding Commission (through an informal dialogue) and integrating experiences of local peacebuilders around COVID-19 in other planned meetings and discussions. The main outputs are: 1) shared the GPPAC COVID-19 Statement with Member States of the PBC, where Canada and the European Union integrated our messaging in their statements; 2) On 11 May 2020, GPPAC alongside the Life and Peace Institute (LPI), and the Permanent Mission of Canada to the United Nations co-organized an informal brown bag discussion to bring together members of the Peacebuilding Commission (PBC) and civil society peacebuilders to engage in joint sharing and learning on a) What does a “peacebuilding response to the COVID-19 pandemic” mean at the field level? and b) How can the PBC meaningfully support local peacebuilding responses? 3) worked with QUNO to develop a two-pager titled "Advancing Prevention Amidst the COVID-19 Pandemic: What Local Civil Society Responses look like and how Peace and Development Advisors can strengthen this work", which was compiled by the Civil Society—UN Prevention Platform to provide an overview of innovative ways local civil society and Peace and Development Advisors (PDAs) are responding to the COVID-19 pandemic. 4) brought in the discussion on COVID-19 and experiences of local peacebuilders in a) SIPRI Forum discussion; b) Regional Dialogue for the Americas; c) the 2020 Review regional consultation in the Americas; 4) the 2020 Review thematic consultation on gender, climate and security in the Pacific; 4) the NYPG-PBSo dialogue; 5) online consultation co-organised by GPPAC for the 2020 Review. 5) hosted the Sustaining Peace roundtable series event on the UN capacities to respond to COVID-19 on the 2nd of June, 2020 under the title 'Building Capacities for Prevention and Sustaining Peace:What can the UN Peacebuilding Architecture learn from the COVID-19 pandemic?'; 6) hosted the CS-UN Prevention Platform to mobilize the discussion on how gender transformative analysis can inform conflict analysis of the COVID-19 dynamics on the 20th of May, 2020 under the title 'Prevention and Implications of COVID-19-19: Learning from Transformative Gender Approaches'

title.narrative: 1.2 Working together

description.narrative: 1.2.2. Civil society reach out to key conflict/prevention stakeholders to engage them in developing inclusive prevention and protection strategies

title.narrative: Advancing policy coherence and linkages between sustainable development and peace

description.narrative: GPPAC works to promote linkages between sustainable development and peace in efforts to a coherent and coordinated approach to the implementation of peacebuilding and sustaining peace. In Quarter 3, a roundtable discussion on ‘Building Peace Infrastructures in Africa’ took place online and saw the participation of a diverse range of participants from across countries and regions who reflected on their perspectives and experiences in building infrastructures for peace. And the online campaign around SDGs was launched: "Every Goal is a peace goal" that featured the contribution of GPPAC network to the implementation of all SDGs through peacebuilding means.

title.narrative: Advancing policy coherence and linkages between sustainable development and peace

description.narrative: GPPAC works to promote linkages between sustainable development and peace in efforts to a coherent and coordinated approach to the implementation of peacebuilding and sustaining peace. The mains outputs are: 1) Together with the TAP Network and CSPPS, GPPAC published the 2020 Review submission titled 'Policy Coherence Through Meaningful Inclusion: The Key Priorities Ahead of the 2020 Peacebuilding Architecture Review'. 2) On the 6th of July 2020, a roundtable discussion on ‘Building Peace Infrastructures in Africa’ took place online and saw the participation of a diverse range of participants from across countries and regions who reflected on their perspectives and experiences in building infrastructures for peace. 3) Online Campaign around SDGs: "Every Goal is a peace goal" that featured the contribution of GPPAC network to the implementation of all SDGs through peacebuilding means.

title.narrative: GPPAC Strategic Input into the 2020 Peacebuilding Architecture Review and the Secretary-General's Report on Peacebuilding and Sustaining Peace

description.narrative: GPPAC, in collaboration with civil society and government partners has conducted a series of activities aimed at providing strategic input into the 2020 Review. This includes capacity building sessions for GPPAC members, written submissions, informal dialogues and formal consultations with relevant peacebuilding stakeholders. It has contributed to the strengthening of civil society engagement with UN actors and member states at all levels, to ensure that civil society perspectives inform global policy on peacebuilding and sustaining peace and to strengthen the recognition of GPPAC expertise by the UN actors at all levels.

description.narrative: Intergovernmental and state actors incorporate people-centred inclusive prevention and protection norms and principles in their policies and decision making processes

title.narrative: Peacebuilding in Patani, Thailand

description.narrative: GPPAC-SEA conducted a experts consultation meeting and a regional workshop/meeting on 20 and 23 of December 2020, respectively. The activity was aimed at updating local stakeholders and regional/GPPAC-SEA partners on peacebuilding in Southeast Asia, including the updates on the peace talks and peace building in Patani, in relation to transitional justice and the UN global ceasefire call and building on an ongoing research on the topic. The outputs of the activity are a)1 research paper developed, and b) 26 local and regional/SEA partners updated on the peace talks in the region and on the ASEAN. This will serve as guidance for consolidating analysis and for strategizing on policy advocacies in the ASEAN.

title.narrative: Regional Training on Peacebuilding and Conflict Transformation in The Philippines

description.narrative: GPPAC-Southeast Asia organised "The Pilot Program of the Regional Training Workshop on Peacebuilding and Conflict Transformation" last 25-30 November 2019 in Penang, Malaysia. Twenty-five participants and facilitators participated in the 4- day training that included field visits and reflective exercises on peace and security issues in the region. The participants are composed of officials from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) officials and representatives from the ministries of foreign affairs, academics and researchers, civil society members and other peace practitioners from Malaysia, Indonesia, Philippines, Thailand and India. This training program aims to encourage sharing and cooperation between official and unofficial tracks in peacebuilding efforts in the region.

title.narrative: GPPAC’s Eastern European network uses mission report in advancing the role of CSOs and preparing consultation on Bessarabia

description.narrative: GPPAC’s Eastern European network was in October 2017 able to conduct a civil monitoring and assessment mission to the Southern Bessarabia region. During the first quarter of 2018, a report on the mission has been drafted and translated to Ukranian, and the network is now utilising said report to prepare a consultation on the question of advancing the role of civil society organizations in conflict prevention and conflict transformation. The possibilities for such a consultation are currently being discussed with the Embassy of the Netherlands in Ukraine.

title.narrative: GPPAC and the UN Human Security Unit have agreed and are working to organise a joint training on human security with the Permanent Peace Movement to be implemented in Lebanon

description.narrative: GPPAC’s Improving Practice Working Group and the UN Human Security Unit are developing a 4-day training on human security, based on the UN’s previous trainings and GPPAC’s Handbook for Human Security. The Permanent Peace Movement is GPPAC’s Regional Secretariat.

title.narrative: Solidarity Newsletter produced on the Government of the Republic of the Philippines (GRP) and the National Democratic Front (NDF) peace process

description.narrative: GPPAC’s Regional Secretariat in South East Asia, Initiatives for International Dialogue, published a solidarity newsletter covering the recent activities and efforts made by the organisation in cooperation with its network partners on the Government of the Republic of the Philippines and the National Democratic Front peace process.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection

title.narrative: Increasing engagement with EU by GPPAC’s South East Asian Regional Secretariat

description.narrative: GPPAC’s South East Asian Regional Secretariat facilitated a training on EU lobbying in January 2018. The training provided greater awareness amongst the South East Asian GPPAC Network members (CSOs) on EU functioning, policies and processes as it relates to peace building and conflict prevention. This is part of a larger growing engagement with the EU in the region, which is especially related to Myanmar and the Philippines, and has led to an agreement between the European Peacebuilding Liaison Office (EPLO) and GPPAC to cooperate on the hosting of the CSDN meeting with EU in Philippines/Mindanao.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: 1.2.1. Civil Society initiates or participates in joint capacity development with state actors on how to work together and operationalise inclusive prevention and protection mechanisms and norms.

title.narrative: Dialogue process on economic blocks in Caucasus leading to society support for recommendations

description.narrative: Georgian-Armenian civil society dialogue in Yerevan discussed how the economic blocks led by Russia and EU, respectively, influence Armenian-Georgian trade and economic relations in the short and mid-term perspectives. The dialogue considered how CSOs can contribute to reduction of conflicts between the competing economic alliances, including secessionist regions. Two thematic meetings in Baku were hosted by Kharabakh Public Council. Georgian, Armenian and Azerbaijani experts prepared three policy papers dealing with prospects of complementarity between the two economic blocks, distributed among the eight state agencies in each country. Participants in the project have increased understanding of the strengthening conflict prevention mechanisms and Infrastructures regarding the two economic blocks and outlined salient issues in trade-economic relations to be addressed in terms of coexistence of the two economic blocks led by Russia and EU, respectively. Increased involvement of media, youth and women in the discussion of conflict and peace issues at the thematic meetings and lobby & advocacy. Recommendations by civil society were reflected in the rhetoric of Georgian and Armenian officials, thanks to the GPPAC supported dialogue process.

title.narrative: 1.3. Improving policy (DD3)

description.narrative: 1.3.1 Network members work together to promote, inform, monitor and contribute to implementing inclusive prevention and protection strategies.

title.narrative: Agreement by Sierra Leone government to include CSOs in an inclusive national peace commission

description.narrative: Hosting of a 2-day strategy workshop on the inclusive development of an independent Infrastructure for Peace in Sierra Leone (4-5 October). This brought together international members from GPPAC, WANEP and 25 civil society members from Sierra Leone to prepare for the planning and establishment of a Peacebuilding and National Cohesion Commission. There was a joint statement by those 25 CSOs from Sierra Leone on the need for such a commission in Sierra Leone. Follow-up advocacy meetings after the event with the project coordinator at United Nations Development Programme, the UN Resident Coordinator as well as the responsible Minister of State of Sierra Leone. Formal agreement by the Sierra Leone government to include a broad range of CSO’s in the setting up of a peace commission, and commitment of State support for the process and engage with the CSO platform.

title.narrative: 1.4. Acting on policies and operationalising norms (DD3)

description.narrative: 1.4.1. Governments and intergovernmental organisations invest in, and collaborate with civil society in coordinated EWER and conflict/situational analysis (including RtoP)

title.narrative: Parties to the Philippines talks recognized the GPPAC civil society organisations network as key actor in peace processes

description.narrative: Hosting of the international solidarity mission to the Philippines with 19 GPPAC participants engaging with parties to the Peace Talks, negotiators and over 20 different CSO stakeholders from key actors working on the peace process and/or affected by the ongoing conflict. New and/or reinforced contacts between GPPAC members of the Working Group Enabling (10 CSOs), Philippines based associates (8 CSOs) and key actors to the Philippines Peace Talks / Peace Process and propositions for continued work by the WG on the talks. Parties to the Philippines talks and broader process recognized the GPPAC network as a knowledgeable resource for providing additional support to the peace process.

title.narrative: 1.3. Improving policy (DD3)

description.narrative: 1.3.3. Intergovernmental and state actors demonstrate readiness to consider civil society - including women and youth - input in official negotiation process

title.narrative: Capacity development of CSOs on Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)

description.narrative: In 2017, GPPAC laid the foundation to provide support to its members in Low and Low-Middle Income Countries on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). An analysis was conducted and translated into a brochure for members on how SDGs can be made relevant at local and national levels. Initial trainings were organised in Southeast Asia. Members in at least 4 countries are more aware of the importance of the SDG process and the Southeast Asian plan for 2018 has taken up the SDGs as one of the priorities to work on internationally through GPPAC.
