description.narrative: In 2019 Q4, UNOY and CSPPS have participated in The Peace Corner Podcast, an initiative to showcase the personal stories of peacebuilders from around the world. In November and December 2019, we released podcasts about the situation in Bolivia, Chile, Uganda, Afghanistan and one on youth inclusion. https://soundcloud.com/user-679057290

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection

title.narrative: Training MENAPPAC members in conflict resolution, conflict analysis, EWER, Human Security, RtoP, PoA

description.narrative: In August and September 2020, GPPAC member PPM held six online training sessions on conflict resolution, conflict analysis, EWER, Human Security, RtoP, PoA (arms) for MENAPPAC members. As a follow-up to the sessions members worked with the concepts and tools in practice, for example by conducting conflict analyses of each others' countries.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: 1.1.2. Network members collaborate to gather and develop civil society resources and expertise on norms and approaches with particular attention on inclusivity

title.narrative: The restoration of peace an official priority in South Kivu Province in the DRC

description.narrative: In December 2019, Mr. Theo Ngwabidje, the Governor of South Kivu Province in the DRC, placed the restoration of peace and security at the top of the priorities of its mandate. After years of political tension and rebel activities, the situation is now calming down in South Kivu province because of this action. GPPAC member has organised training sessions for government and state actors in South Kivu as part of its advocacy work. The civil society, local authorities, Human Rights Defenders and local communities have continued to engage their leaders like the Governor on the importance of prioritizing peace and human rights in South Kivu as well as the rest of the county. On January 9 and 10 of 2020, in the territory of Uvira in the DRC, several outlaws responsible for looting and hostage-taking were arrested following the set-up of a toll-free number available to the public for alerting the authorities about criminal activities as well as the re-establishment of night patrols. Both initiatives came out of the emergency GPPAC-funded project implemented in December 2019 by GPPAC member in the DRC, Héritiers de la Justice.

title.narrative: 1.4. Acting on policies and operationalising norms

description.narrative: Governments and intergovernmental institutions take steps to act on policies and operationalise norms and frameworks for conflict prevention and the protection of people and collaborate with civil society

title.narrative: Establishment of the Nigeria Youth Peace Forum in Nigeria

description.narrative: In December 2019, participants of Nigeria Youth for Peace Forum established the Nigeria Coalition on Youth, Peace and Security - a coalition of over 60 organisations which was hitherto not in existence to help galvanise support and resources in moving the youth, peace and security agenda forward in Nigeria. It is significant because up to now there was no existing coalition or network on youth, peace and security. This outcome means that there is now an entry point to begin conversation with the legislative body on strengthening young people's participation in peacebuilding in Lagos and Nigeria.

title.narrative: 1.3. Improving policy and adopting recommendations

description.narrative: Intergovernmental and state actors incorporate people-centred inclusive prevention and protection norms and principles in their policies and decision making processes

title.narrative: GPPAC South East Asia leads training program in collaboration with Asean on conflict transformation and prevention

description.narrative: In January 2020, the Governing Council and the Advisory Board of the ASEAN Institute for Peace and Reconciliation (ASAN-IPR) decided to conduct joint trainings on Conflict Transformation and Mediation Processes with GPPAC-Southeast Asia for the next three years. The Malaysian MFA will lead the fundraising, and GPPAC-Southeast Asia Working Group will lead the program and content of the trainings.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: The networks and network members build support for conflict prevention by engaging with and building capacities of key stakeholders

title.narrative: “Culture of Good Neighborhood Course ” and the “Living in Peace and Harmony” Peace Education courses, developed by GPPAC Members in Eastern Europe, were presented to local primary schools in Moldova (and Transnistria)

description.narrative: In July and August 2019, the Culture of Good Neighborhood course was presented to teachers and principals of many Moldovan schools. They were told about its importance, the methods of teaching; and the possibilities of using its elements in teaching other subjects, in those schools where it is not yet possible to introduce this course in full. “The Living in Peace and Harmony” was a similar course covering the same topics of peacebuilding and conflict resolution.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: The networks and network members build support for conflict prevention by engaging with and building capacities of key stakeholders

title.narrative: Officials from Georgia and Armenia recognise their complementary economic ties and resume economic relations in May-June 2019 partially due to the advocacy efforts by the GPPAC South Caucasus regional network.

description.narrative: In May 2019, the work of the Georgian-Armenian intergovernmental commission on trade and economic cooperation has been restored after an 8-year break, and the first session took place in June 2019. Additionally, in June, the Armenian city of Dilizhan hosted the Georgian-Armenian economic and business forum aiming to propel bilateral economic relations to a new level. The change can be partially attributed to- along with other actors’ efforts- GPPAC South Caucasus regional network and the advocacy work of GPPAC Regional Secretariat in the South Caucasus, International Centre of Conflict and Negotiation, in 2017-2018 through the publishing of policy papers and media reports, as well as various experts-level meetings. The resumption of the suspended economic ties, especially at an official and high profile level is vital, as it significantly diminishes the probability of conflict and/or conflict-prone developments.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: The networks and network members build support for conflict prevention by engaging with and building capacities of key stakeholders

title.narrative: Peace Education actors in Moldova collaborate jointly in course "Culture of Good Neighborhood"

description.narrative: In Moldova the 4th grade peace education program was developed during the spring and summer of 2017. The course is called “Culture of good neighborhood” and has been undergoing testing in 32 schools in Moldova (including the Transnistria region), involving more than 1200 pupils. On 27 December 2017, over 40 teachers and managers from different localities of the country, as well as the representatives of the Ministry of Education, Culture and Research and of the General Departments of Education participated at the final Conference of the project “Peace education through promoting culture of good neighborhood in primary schools”.

title.narrative: DD3 - 1.2 - Working together

description.narrative: 1.2.2 Civil society reach out to key conflict/prevention stakeholders to engage them on developing inclusive prevention and protection strategies

title.narrative: More than half of the teachers in Moldova (including the disputed region of Transnistria) opted to begin teaching the “Culture of Good Neighborhood” Peace Education course in their schools on August 8th, 2019.

description.narrative: In Moldova, practitioners (GPPAC members) prepared and distributed the “Culture of Good Neighborhood” course in the region, encouraging teachers to offer this peacebuilding course regionally

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: The networks and network members build support for conflict prevention by engaging with and building capacities of key stakeholders

title.narrative: In the 2018-2019 school year, an increasing number of schools and teachers in the Transnistrian region are teaching the GPPAC regionally-developed course “Living in peace and consent”, and use the materials in other activities.

description.narrative: In Moldova, there is an unresolved territorial dispute over the separatist region of Transnistria. For the long-term resolution of this conflict and other societal issues, it is important that children are educated on peace and tolerance. GPPAC members from Ukraine and Moldova have been working on the development of this peace education curriculum since 2013, and have been training teachers on its use. The course is based on a similar course GPPAC members -previously based in Crimea- had developed.

title.narrative: Outcome 1.1 - Civil society capacity 1.1.2 Network members collaborate to gather and develop civil, society resources and expertise on norms and approaches with particular attention on inclusivity (including manuals, tools, guidelines, trainings, trained trainers or resource persons, case studies)
Georgian youth and historical memory in conflicts

description.narrative: In November 2020, the students of Georgian Ilia State University started to actively study the role of history and historical memory in conflicts. After publishing the policy paper and its presentation, the Students’ History Club of Ilia State University of Georgia plans to continue engaging with youth about the role of history and historical memory in the developing and resolution of conflicts, especially those in Georgia, including the role of the youth in rethinking the roots of conflicts. Several professors of Ilia University expressed readiness to consult the Club members to make the discussions more academic and meaningful. Prior to the engagement with GPPAC program the Club was less proactive in this field.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: 1.2.2. Civil society reach out to key conflict/prevention stakeholders to engage them in developing inclusive prevention and protection strategies

title.narrative: Peace Education Webinars: Rwanda and Mexico

description.narrative: In November we offered a webinar on peace education in Rwanda, focused on a successful model for peace education, supporting tens of thousands of young people across the country with the knowledge and skills to overcome the legacy of genocide. In December, a webinar on confronting social conflict in Mexico focused on the development of knowledge, skills and aptitudes for the construction of peace through various nonviolent strategies.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection

title.narrative: Georgian state agencies agreed to use of conflict prevention tools.

description.narrative: In October 2019, during the workshop “Inclusion of civic sector in the process of conflict prevention for better inculcation of conflict prevention tools in the government’s policies and strategies” held in Tbilisi, three state agencies in Georgia: Government’s State Chancellery, the State Minister’s Apparatus for Reconciliation and Equality and Ministry of Internal Affairs have agreed to continue cooperation with ICCN about use of conflict prevention tools before taking action, such as to do a conflict analysis before implementing specific actions in order to prevent conflict and violence. Given worsening state and human security situation along the administrative border line between Georgia and South Ossetia and Abkhazia since October 2019 even verbally expressed willingness of the state agencies to consider the ICCN recommendations about conflict prevention tools is a significant marker.

title.narrative: 1.4. Acting on policies and operationalising norms

description.narrative: Governments and intergovernmental institutions take steps to act on policies and operationalise norms and frameworks for conflict prevention and the protection of people and collaborate with civil society

title.narrative: Peace Education Webinar Series

description.narrative: In Q1 2019, GPPAC’s Peace Education Working Group launched its Peace Education Webinar series, which has GPPAC’s peace education experts sharing their experience on integrating peace education into formal (schools, colleges and universities) and informal (community) education structures. Audience Three episodes have been released, “Building Capacity from a Local to Global Level”; “School Mediation in Multi-Ethnic Communities in Serbia”; and “Inclusive Education in Multicultural Societies”. There were totally 60 participant: predominantly peace education practitioners and decision makers from various organisations and institutions.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: 1.2.1. Civil Society initiates or participates in joint capacity development with state actors on how to work together and operationalise inclusive prevention and protection mechanisms and norms.

title.narrative: Commitment of youth as peace ambassadors now engaged in promoting peace in their respective families and communities in Cameroon

description.narrative: In September 2020, 100 youth (48 female and 52 male) committed to becoming peace ambassadors and are now engaged in promoting peace in their respective families and communities in Cameroon. The peace ambassadors attributed this to the transformation in their mindset – following a 2020 youth peace camp organized during the International peace week in which youth learned about peacebuilding, career building and life skills.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: 1.2.2. Civil society reach out to key conflict/prevention stakeholders to engage them in developing inclusive prevention and protection strategies

title.narrative: Improved coexistence between internally displaced people and host communities in Somalia

description.narrative: In September/October 2019, internally displaced persons and host communities in the Bandir region, Somalia, improved their co-existence and now can live together in peace and harmony. This was realized through Save Somali Women and Children, GPPAC member, initiating social cohesion and integration interventions as a means of preventing violent conflict that emanate from tensions arising from social differences

title.narrative: 1.4. Acting on policies and operationalising norms

description.narrative: Governments and intergovernmental institutions take steps to act on policies and operationalise norms and frameworks for conflict prevention and the protection of people and collaborate with civil society

title.narrative: Southeast Asian analysis and capacity building plan on lobby & advocacy of CSOs

description.narrative: In Southeast Asia the GPPAC Regional Secretariat conducted a survey among regional members to identify the capacities and needs to develop additional capacities in lobby and advocacy for conflict prevention and peacebuilding. The regional network agreed on a framework for a regional capacity building program that will be set up and starting early 2018.

title.narrative: 1.1 - Civil society capacity

description.narrative: 1.1.1 Network members engage in regional and cross-regional exchanges, working groups and action research on priority themes

title.narrative: Asia-Pacific civil society organisations, United Nations, World Bank (WB) and other key actors to act nationally on “Pathways to Peace” process

description.narrative: In coordination with UNDP Headquarters, GPPAC hosted a 3-day meeting on the UN-WB report on Pathways to Peace in Bangkok with aim to translate the findings on the ground and facilitate cooperation between civil society organisations and in-country actors. GPPAC members established links between civil society organisations and UNDP, DPA, PBSO and World Bank representatives from Asia and Pacific for further national level discussions. As a result of the meeting, advocacy contacts were established for GPPAC members to follow-up discussions in country for the Philippines, Cambodia, Sri Lanka and Maldives.

title.narrative: 1.4. Acting on policies and operationalising norms (DD3)

description.narrative: 1.4.2. Governments take steps to implement NAPs and strategies on WPS, YPS, VE, RtoP in collaboration with civil society

title.narrative: During the Young Peacebuilders Forum in 2019, where GPPAC members participated, partnerships were developed amongst the participants, funding opportunities were offered and the visibility of the Youth, Peace and Security agenda was expanded.

description.narrative: In its fifth edition, this Forum took place in Bogotá, Colombia, with a strong regional emphasis. Bringing together 60 young peacebuilders, the Forum provided a unique space to build concrete and meaningful partnerships beyond mere networking. The four-day event saw multi-angled discussions around the role of global agendas in peacebuilding processes in the Americas and beyond, engaging with a range of relevant stakeholders, such as representatives from the Colombian Truth Commission (Comisión de la Verdad) and the Special Jurisdiction for Peace (Jurisdicción Especial para la Paz), as well as thematic experts. During the forum, 20 formal partnerships were forged among participants, 5 media outlets covered the event, 5 forum initiatives were offered comprehensive funding opportunities, and a living library was formed.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection

title.narrative: The Youth, Peace, and Security (YPS) Working Group has been created in June 2018, in efforts to mainstream youth in GPPAC’s peacebuilding work, and to further the advocacy efforts of global youth peacebuilders

description.narrative: In line with GPPAC’s Strategic Plan 2016-2020, the YPS Working Group was launched with UNOY (United Network of Young Peacebuilders) as its chair. The group consists of 13 GPPAC member organisations, and 23 youth-led members of UNOY. The working group aims to become a platform that localises UNSCR Resolution 2250 through collaboration, sharing best practices and intergenerational dialogue; develops GPPAC’s youth policy; and provides the opportunity for youth-led UNOY members to become involved in the GPPAC network.

title.narrative: 1.1 Civil society capacity (DD5)

description.narrative: 1.1.1. Network members engage in regional and cross-regional exchanges, working groups and action research on priority themes (including PVE, PE, RtoP, WPS)

title.narrative: Joint advocacy project for Income development for unemployed youth and women in Iraq

description.narrative: In post ISIS Iraq, ​​this project supports those who have been greatly affected and have to build their lives again. Income development for the benefit of (480) beneficiaries of unemployed young men and women with dependents for their families, from the displaced indigenous returnees in Anbar Governorate, through a comprehensive field survey aimed at (850) cases / families, and according to the criteria of vulnerability and need, (480) were selected. Beneficiary and provision of conditional financial grants to establish a small income-generating project, preceded by providing training for them on market assessment, project idea identification, feasibility study work, project management / finance, marketing and competition. The project also provides dialogue sessions to introduce concepts and spread a culture of tolerance and social solidarity.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection

title.narrative: Between April and July 2019, GPPAC CSOs and experts from Georgia and Azerbaijan agreed to create a Georgian-Azerbaijani civil forum to tackle unaddressed conflict between the two countries.

description.narrative: In the backdrop of accumulating unresolved or unaddressed conflict-prone issues between Georgia and Azerbaijan, CSOs from both countries proposed the creation of a Georgian-Azerbaijani civil forum. Additionally, Georgian and Azerbaijani experts agreed to support the creation of a forum, and draft a joint address to the governments of both countries to offer their expertise in addressing conflict-prone situations.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection

title.narrative: Media outlets in Armenia, Georgia and Azerbaijan more intesively published reports and articles on conflict prevention and peacebuilding after GPPAC-convened meetings

description.narrative: In the first quarter of 2019 the participant media outlets of meetings convened by GPPAC, including Civilnet (Armenia), Newsday (Georgia), Studio Re (Georgia), Turan (Azerbaijan) published reports and articles about conflict prevention and peace building more intensively than before. The media plays a significant role both in triggering and relieving conflict. CivilNet promptly organized a live online conference with an ICCN representative (GPPAC Regional Secretariat for South Caucasus) to make clarifications on the conflict-prone situation associated with the restrictions of the transit of cereals to Armenia by automotive transport through Georgia, which unleashed some anti-Georgian sentiments in the Armenian communities.

title.narrative: GPPAC is providing financial and technical support to the development and incorporation of community resilience and Countering Violent Extremism (CVE) strategies in peace education in the Sahel region

description.narrative: In the second quarter of 2018, the development of Terms of Reference and identification of the consultant for the curriculum development were concluded. In addition, GPPAC’s West African Regional Secretariat (WANEP) and its partners continued to actively engage communities in the development of resilience mechanisms on human security and prevention of violent extremism.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity (DD3)

description.narrative: 1.1.4. Network members work together to inform, monitor and contribute to implementing prevention and protection strategies (incl WPS, PVE)

title.narrative: Conflict Resolution and Crisis Management in the Pandemic COVID-19 in East Nusa Tenggara (Indonesia)

description.narrative: Indonesia focal point Ichsan Malik Centre and local partner Institute of Resource Governance and Social Change (IRGSC) conducted a capacity building activity last 12-13 November 2020. Since the emergence of covid 19 cases in NTT, suspected of covid victims have been experiencing stigma from the community members. This training was implemented to equip health workers from the Health Community Centre in Kupang to deal with the conflict when they perform their job to do tracing of covid 19 victims. The activity was attended by more than 20 health workers, family members of the COVID-19 victims, laboran of the Laboratorium Biomolekuler NTT, public officials from the Department of Health, Department of Transportation and Port Health Office. Based on the pre and post test that we conducted, knowledge and skills of the participants increased after they attended this two days training.

description.narrative: It is a new tool to keep the Working Group and its local partners updated on the peace process in the Philippines. The current format is based on a regular monitoring started by Conciliation Resources.

title.narrative: Women and youth leaders in Northern Cameroon participated in community dialogues and decision making at grassroots level in June 2019, based on learnings from GPPAC, thereby contributing to the objectives of UN security council resolutions 1325 and 2250

description.narrative: Justine Kwachu of Women in Alternative Action (WAA) Cameroon used learnings from the GPPAC network and her participation in GPPAC activities as a Gender Focal person to mainstream gender in WAA approaches like peace education in schools, kids for peace program, and “Queens for Peace”. Queens for Peace is an innovative initiative that brings on board women in traditional institutions to participate in peace processes and decision making at the grassroots level.

The purpose of the Network is involving and strengthening women mediators in peace processes before, during and after conflicts. description.narrative: NGO Working Group on Women Peace and Security accepted GPPAC’s application to become a member. By joining the working group GPPAC’s advocacy on inclusive conflict prevention in relation to our work on Women, Peace and Security is strengthened and it also provides a platform for network members to provide recommendations on inclusivity and conflict prevention across the UN system and member states on thematic and country specific issues.

title.narrative: For the first time, the Netherlands Clingendael Institute has invited GPPAC to provide a seminar of 3 hours as part of the official pre-deployment training week to personnel of the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA) for civilian missions, in July 2019, for an honorarium

description.narrative: Netherlands Clingendael Institute invited GPPAC’s Training and Capacity Building Coordinator to provide this training. It is the first time GPPAC receives such an invitation from Clingendael, which is an indication of recognition of GPPAC’s knowledge of the subject matter. Also, it is an opportunity to directly influence the MFA personnel undergoing this training, to focus on themes GPPAC finds important. The training focused on the civil society / NGO perspective on EU/UN missions, with some case studies including Mali, focused on Human Security and Local ownership.

description.narrative: Nine civil society organisations that are members of the GPPAC working group on Preventing Violent Extremism (PVE) met on 30 November - 1 December 2018 in Manilla, The Philippines, to review and update the submitted position papers on PVE situations and strategies in various GPPAC regions (a.o. West Africa, South East Asia, MENA) and what role GPPAC and its members are/can play. WANEP participated and submitted a position paper based on its long time experience in working on those issues in West Africa.

description.narrative: OSCE Conflict Prevention Center (CPC) updated and designed their Conflict Analysis tools using GPPAC’s Conflict Analysis Field guidelines and procedures handbook as its main resource. In addition, GPPAC’s Conflict Analysis Field guide is from October 2018 onwards included in the official mapping of the EU on conflict analysis tools, which is their starting point for updating the EU’s official Conflict Analysis Guidance Note.

description.narrative: On 10 September 2019 in Bangkok, GPPAC members participated in the ASEAN Civil Society Conference/Peoples Forum 2019 Workshop “Rising Populism and ‘Othering’ in ASEAN: Protecting Rights and Freedoms of Ethnic-Religious and Queer Communities”. The conference gathered multiple civil society organizations, including both GPPAC members and non-members.

title.narrative: Global advocacy on gender by the GPPAC Delegation in Commission on the Status of Women 63 (CSW63)

description.narrative: On 11-15 March 2019, GPPAC co-hosted one civil society panel, contributed a speaker to an event hosted by CSPPS and to a high level event hosted by UN Women. The delegation consisted of GPPAC members including Gender Focal Points and representatives from the Youth, Peace and Security Working Group. Six key events were co-organised and/or included active advocacy interventions by GPPAC members. GPPAC organised a side event with ICRtoP and Friedrich Ebert Stiftung New York Office jointly: “Sustainable Infrastructure for Gender Equality: Putting Prevention Up Front”. Chair of GPPACs Board and Gender Liaison spoke at High Level Panel: The Road to 2020: Accelerating Action on Women, Peace and Security, alongside with the executive director of UN Women, several Permanent Members to UN (including Canada) and CSO representatives. The event has been live streamed on UN Web TV, and covered in reflective articles written by UN Women, and one by GPPACs Board and Gender Liaison.

title.narrative: 1.3. Improving policy

title.narrative: The UN Women Executive Director stressed the role of youth in leading the way forward in implementing the Beijing Platform for Action at CSW63

description.narrative: On 13 March 2019 the UN Women Director highlighted and recognised the role and contribution of young women: “When we celebrate 25 years [of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action], my commitment to you is that you will be there. You will speak for yourselves. You will tell us what you want and the future you want.” At the INTERGENERATIONAL DIALOGUE "TAKE THE HOT SEAT" organized by UN Women, UN Secretary General's Envoy on Youth, Girls Scouts and the Working Group on Girls at the 63rd session of the Commission on the Status of Women. GPPAC played an active role during CSW63. The GPPAC chair of the Youth Peace and Security Working Group was one of the few young participants and provided expert input in the advocacy process, including for the preparatory UN Women panel “Sustainable Infrastructure for Gender Equality: Putting Prevention Up Front”.

description.narrative: On 14 April 2019, GPPAC member Tunisian Youth Council organised a meeting for civil society organisations to introduce GPPAC and GPPAC in the Middle East and North Africa (MENAPPAC), and explore the possibility of setting up a Tunisian GPPAC network with 18 CSOs, similar to already existing national networks in Syria and Iraq. The participants agreed to develop a conflict analysis for Tunisia, after which MENAPPAC well provide training in applying human security principles to address conflicts.

description.narrative: On 14 July 2020, after the Online roundtable discussion on Building Peace Infrastructures in Africa the UN Peace And Development Advisor (PDA) in Cameroon reached out to GPPAC with the request to get to know GPPAC members in Cameroon and suggested GPPAC member WAA to be in the lead of mapping civil society in Cameroon. The engagement demonstrates the convening capacity of GPPAC and recognizes the expertise of GPPAC members with the UN at national level as well as the credibility of GPPAC members as partners of the UN.

title.narrative: GPPAC organised policy dialogue on the Dutch Integrated External and Security Strategy to provide input to its implementation

description.narrative: On 14 June 2018, GPPAC and the Quaker Council for European Affairs (QCEA) organised a policy discussion in the Hague on “The Implementation of National Security Strategies: How to ensure national ownership for legitimacy and long-term impact?” It was organised in the context of the implementation of the recently published Dutch Integrated External and Security Strategy 2018-22, which GPPAC had provided significant input to in the first quarter of 2018. Speakers included an EU official from the European External Action Service.

description.narrative: On 18 December 2020, during an online meeting "Dialogue and peacebuilding" which was attended by 24 representatives of universities from 8 regions of Ukraine and peacebuilding practitioners, the GPPAC network has expanded the list of universities with which there is an opportunity to cooperate in the future. The meeting received positive feedback from participants. The regional network received two reply letters with agreements to cooperate with the Kyiv National Taras Shevchenko University and South Unkrainian National Pedagogical University.

title.narrative: Normalizing public discourse around LGBT issues in Eastern Europe

description.narrative: On 19 October 2020, the WIPD and the gender direction of the Eastern European GPPAC network agreed to collaborate to unite efforts for more active implementation of UNSC Resolution 1325 (on Women, Peace, and Security) in the region. From 20 October 2020 to 28 December 2020, the mini-project “Belarusian Case 1325” studied the meanings attributed to women politicians by public figures in Belarus, Ukraine, and the Russian Federation, the difference in positions depending on the political and other orientations of speakers, to characterize the perception of women politicians in public space, expectations from them and in connection with their appearance, as well as the prospects for the development of this topic. The results of the project will be used for the further development of the direction and broad discussion with organizations that work with the gender issues.

description.narrative: On 29 March 2019, GPPAC’s Enabling Collaboration Working Group - through consultation and meetings with partners and together with Lumad Husay Mindanaw - created a statement in response to the Executive Order 70 for the creation of the national task force to end local communist armed conflict. This is part of GPPAC’s global Working Group’s efforts to regularly monitor the developments of the Philippines peace process, craft position or analysis papers, and issue statements when necessary.

title.narrative: Eight Tunisian civil society organisations created a new national GPPAC network ‘TunisiaPPAC’ in May 2019 to unite for conflict prevention and peacebuilding.

description.narrative: On April 2019, Permanent Peace Movement, GPPAC Middle East and North Africa’s Regional Secretariat convened a national meeting of Tunisian CSOs to explain GPPAC and its regional work to encourage Tunisian CSOs to form a national platform. GPPAC’s Tunisian members organised a meeting to form their national network in a rural area to ensure that the network and process are inclusive, not just for urban elite. The newly formed national network is recognised by peacebuilding organisations in Tunisia. The objectives of the national network are to provide a platform for the members to work together to deal with the challenges the country is facing; and recognise the importance of a network approach to deal with issues related to peace, conflict prevention, and human rights.

title.narrative: Normalizing the public discourse around LGBT issues in Ukraine.

description.narrative: On May 7, 2020, a webinar was held focused on combining peacebuilding and gender perspectives, named “Talking about the Difficult” for the NGO “Insight” with a wide range of participants from 9 regions of Ukraine. Members of EE GPPAC were able to draw attention to and engage in a broad discussion among members of the LGBTIQ+ community about the importance of using conflict resolutions and peacebuilding methods in the challenges they can respond to in their daily lives. For this, the example of a real “Belarus case” was used, which was decomposed into stages of the conflict, the analysis of stakeholder relations, cartography of the conflict, and positions-interests-needs of the parties.

title.narrative: Documentary on Religious Minorities in Myanmar

description.narrative: Our local partner Myanmar Cultural Research Society produced a short video documentary on Understanding Diversity, Uplifting Equality and Promoting Harmony entitled "Shia: Followers of Ali," to share about the historical existence of Shia Islamic communities and the diversity of faith and historical backgrounds in Myanmar/Burma. The documentary is based on ethnic research collection of MCRS and it is linked with culture and heritage places that are of great value to local Shia communities. MCRS organized interviews with key people from this community which is one of the many discriminated communities in the country.

title.narrative: CSO recommendation in the report of the UN Secretary General on Women, Peace and Security

description.narrative: Report of the UN Secretary General on Women, Peace and Security published on 9 October 2019 has included recommendations relevant for conflict prevention. It informs the United Nations, Member States and regional organizations on the progress of the implementation of WPS agenda and promotes women’s rights, gender equality and the full and meaningful participation of women across all decision-making contexts. Due to this advocacy, the language now included in the Report strengthens it’s conflict prevention aspects from the perspectives of local peacebuilders from GPPACs network. GPPAC is an active member of the NGO Working Group on Women Peace and Security and provided input for the SG’s report on WPS based recommendations of GPPAC Gender experts accumulated in GPPACs knowledge products.

title.narrative: Integrating the “Culture of good neighbourhood” course in primary schools in Moldova

description.narrative: Several activities were undertaken to train teachers on interactive teaching methods, with an emphasis on resolving educational conflicts that arise in their schools due to ethnic, religious, social diversity, and intercultural issues. A webinar was organized on-line with 2 groups of teachers (Romanian and Russian speakers) and video lessons developed. As an impact, over 800 children will benefit from an important educational innovation, developed also based on the intercultural education students workbook ""Culture of Good Neighborhood"".

title.narrative: GPPAC South Caucasus grows with six new members

description.narrative: Six experienced CSOs from Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan have become GPPAC members. The joining of new members is essential because it increases the capacity of GPPAC South Caucasus Network, diversifies its peace activities and amplifies advocacy potential. Each new member has its unique capacity in the various fields of peace activity ranging from grant-making and youth-led activities to a think tank and advocacy.

title.narrative: Awareness-raising in South Caucasus on Conflict Prevention

description.narrative: Six featured stories were published highlighting methods of early response to conflict-prone situations, prevention of conflict escalation and peace and confidence building. Articles published online are: “The role of women in peace” at www.ginsc.net, “independence inside the cell’, “Friends' second appeal to their societies” & “Choice at the request of the client” at Meydan.tv about the Armenian-Azerbaijani war

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

title.narrative: Women in 32 villages of Sool and Sanaag regions (eastern regions) of Somaliland are now able to engage with traditional leaders and have them recognise the views of women during peace negotiations, in part as a result of the work of GPPAC national focal point organisation for Somaliland, NAGAAD. As of June 2019, at least 2 women actively participate as peace committee members at village and district levels.

description.narrative: Somaliland is a country influenced by a traditional male dominated clan system. GPPAC’s Eastern and Central African members have undergone a number of capacity building trainings on gender, women participation, negotiation and mediation, and advocacy. In 2018, one of the trainings emphasised skills on how to conduct constructive and conflict sensitive advocacy especially in fragile contexts and where cultural practices are hostile to women participation. NAGAAD, GPPAC member and focal point organisation for Somaliland, applied these skills to foster women participation in peacebuilding processes like negotiations. NAGAAD also cascaded the knowledge gained from this training to women peace coalitions to strengthen their advocacy, negotiation and mediation skills.

title.narrative: Teachers in Moldova introduce the celebration of the Day of Tolerance

description.narrative: Teachers, inspired by the GPPAC peace education program, for the first time organized activities dedicated to the International Day of Tolerance in their classes in the Anenii Noi district of Moldova. More than 4000 students from 27 schools, 5-12 grades, and approx. 400 teachers were formed in the field of intercultural education and peace education. The aim was to inform students about the need for tolerance in society and to help children understand the negative effects of intolerance.

title.narrative: The Embassy of the Kyrgyz Republic in Belgium has established a direct information exchange (via online group chat) with the school children of a GPPAC project who are young activists representing 4 regions and 8 communities in Kyrgyzstan, in June 2019.

description.narrative: The 17 June meeting between participants in the project ‘Cameras in Hands’ and the Embassy of the Kyrgyz Republic in Belgium was organised as part of the GPPAC youth empowerment project. The role of youth in initiating and leading changes in the country was acknowledged by the Embassy: “It was a pleasure to meet and talk to active boys and girls, who are from the young age trying to influence with their actions the life of their communities and the country and change it for the better” - says the post of the embassy. https://www.instagram.com/p/By1-s8Ro3RY/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link

title.narrative: Implementation of Peace Education (PE) programme in Moldova/Transnistria

description.narrative: The 4th grade programme “Culture of good neighbourhood” is continuously being implemented in 35 schools. This is the last phase of the piloting, after which the programme will be analysed, the curriculum improved, and the programme expanded. During the spring of 2018, network members have discussed key steps towards launching a strategy of nation-wide integration of a peace education curricula for the elementary schools in Moldova/Transnistria.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working Together

description.narrative: 1.2.2. Civil society reach out to key conflict/prevention stakeholders to engage them on developing inclusive prevention and protection strategies

title.narrative: Baseline Research on Youth-Focused Policy and Programs in the Philippines

description.narrative: The 50-page research paper was written with 10 recommendations after identifying gaps and challenges in reviewing existing programs and policy that directly relates to youth in conflict affected and conflict vulnerable areas.The research developed recommendations towards mainstreaming UNSCR 2250 in the Philippines. It looked into national policies and programming of 4 agencies in 5 target areas and reviewed policies and programs that engages and supports youth in peacebuilding work and service delivery to youth affected by conflict from January 2016 to October 2019.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection

title.narrative: The African Union’s Conflict Prevention and Early Warning Division expanded the scope of its Africa Reporter Tool training for GPPAC members.

description.narrative: The Africa Reporter tool is a mechanism for collecting conflict early warning data at their observation and monitoring centre, ‘The Situation Room’. GPPAC’s Regional Secretariat ECLF was able to convince the Conflict Prevention and Early Warning Division of the African Union’s Peace and Security Department to train all members of the SAPPC Regional Steering Group, expanding the scope of the program beyond the initial 1 GPPAC member invited to the training. This training on how to collect data for the AU’s continental early warning system will build GPPAC members’ capacities and credibility in early warning and early response (EWER) and allow them to engage on the topic for future regional intergovernmental EWER initiatives.

title.narrative: 1.4. Acting on policies and operationalising norms

description.narrative: Governments and intergovernmental institutions take steps to act on policies and operationalise norms and frameworks for conflict prevention and the protection of people and collaborate with civil society

title.narrative: Activities of the Chernivtsi conflict prevention expert group in Ukraine

description.narrative: The Chernivtsi Expert Group on Conflict Prevention met in September to discuss conflict-related factors in connection with local elections and ways to minimize conflicts caused by the implementation of decentralization reform in Ukraine. Network members of EE GPPAC regional network participated in: - Holding international (Ukraine, Romania, Moldova, Belarus, Poland, Hungary) round tables and conferences to overcome historical resentment - Communication with local and international media (radio & TV), which promotes dialogue in polyethnic communities (Ukraine, Moldova) - Preparation for participation in an international conference (Ukraine, Moldova, Romania), dedicated to the history of the region and historical figures who made efforts to unite the region.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: 1.2.2. Civil society reach out to key conflict/prevention stakeholders to engage them in developing inclusive prevention and protection strategies

title.narrative: Advocacy and develop UN Staff capacities for inclusive engagement with civil society on the ground

description.narrative: The Civil Society-UN Prevention Platform - which GPPAC co-facilitates with the Quaker United Nations Office (QUNO) - in close collaboration with the UN UNDP-DPPA Joint Programme on to Build National Capacities (Joint Programme) launched a project focused on the UN Peace and Development Advisors (PDAs). PDAs serve to build linkages between the UN’s political and developmental efforts ‘on the ground’. This project contributes to lessons-learned and best practices on engagement between PDAs and local CSOS to ensure inclusive and meaningful engagement with all marginalized communities and overall to strengthen the UN’s engagement with civil society on the ground.

description.narrative: The Countering Violent Extremism curriculum focuses on formal schools, but WANEP aims to disseminate the curriculum in informal settings as well. During the validation meeting, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS)’s Directorate of Education, Youth and Sports, and the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) were present.

description.narrative: The Dutch Embassy expressed their interest appreciation of the GPPAC missions and resulting studies. The new one is planned for the Zakarpattia area in the Ukraine to take part in November 2018.

title.narrative: The Dutch Integrated National Security Strategy has taken up human security as a key starting point in their security strategy published in the first months of 2018.

description.narrative: The Dutch MFA has now taken human security as starting point for its new security strategy as a key starting point. During 2017, GPPAC co-organised strategic discussions with CSOs active in Peace & Security and the MFA on the new Dutch security strategy, emphasising the need to put human security at the core of this strategy. GPPAC also shared the GPPAC-QUNO report on Building Sustainable Peace with key actors within the MFA. Through these activities and engagements GPPAC has contributed to this outcome.

title.narrative: On 15 August 2018, CSOs meet to strategically engage with Government Task Force: CECORE and PeaceNet organized a national platform meeting for 20 CSOs to evaluate the government-led Building Bridges Initiative and to develop recommendations to build lasting unity in Kenya

description.narrative: The Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands in Nairobi participated in the meeting.

title.narrative: The European Commission’s PRISM Division agreed to take up specific recommendations from GPPAC regarding its Conflict Analysis Guidance Note in March 2019

description.narrative: The European External Action Service (EEAS) Prevention of Conflict, Rule of Law/Security Sector Reform, Integrated Approach, Stabilisation and Mediation (PRISM) is leading the revision of the European Commission’s Conflict Analysis Guidance Note, which is aimed at EU institutions, and influences the way EU institutions act, and how they should buy-in to and conduct conflict analysis in their work. GPPAC made specific recommendations that helped shaping gender mainstreaming and a section on limitations.

title.narrative: Representatives of different civil organizations in the Chernivtsi region of Ukraine agreed to joint interventions aimed at preventing conflicts during the electoral period

description.narrative: The GPPAC Network’s activities in Ukraine created the Chernivtsi expert group for preventing conflicts and dangerous escalations during the electoral period early 2019, by 16 regional experts and including representatives of different ethno-cultural groups. The platform works to address the challenges of a country affected by ‘hybrid war’ in which misinformation and positioning different groups against each other is a common practice.

Through the webinars, GPPAC's peace education experts share their decades of experience integrating peace education into formal (schools, colleges and universities) and informal (community) education structures.

The meeting was held back-to-back with the Conference on Peace and the Prevention of Violent Extremism. GPPAC Global Secretariat also participated and the SEA members had a prominent role in the conference, including as facilitators of group discussions.

description.narrative: The GPPAC-coordinated and funded group met on 18-20 May 2018. They identified co-leaders and gender experts to steer the capacity building courses. Thematically, it was decided to focus on conflict analysis, human security and approaches to peace processes. It was also agreed on to seek partnership with the ASEAN Institute for Peace and Reconciliation.

description.narrative: The GPPAC’s Improving Practice Working Group presented common elements and key considerations for multi-stakeholder processes, including a case study from the Southern Africa Region. This webinar “Setting up Multi-Stakeholder Processes for Human Security: Common Elements and a Case Study” was based on GPPAC’s “Multi-Stakeholder Processes for Conflict Prevention and Peacebuilding: A Manual” and is made available online.

The group worked through a number of modules and case studies from the Handbook on Human Security and deliberated on planning for 2018.

Working Group Meeting to Strengthen Our Members’ Capacity for Conflict Analysis

description.narrative: The Improving Practice Working Group held their meeting on 3-4 October 2019 in Vienna on Conflict Analysis. The meeting built the capacity of the working group member through a horizontal learning exchange, and has started to result in new endeavors between participants. The draft of the final report can be found here: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1xGdQPneh9mSj6zBgLy6T30

title.narrative: Localizing the United Nations Security Council Resolution 2250 on Youth, Peace and Security in Nigeria.

description.narrative: The Nigerian Youth For Peace Forum was convened to raise awareness and develop strategies and action plan for the implementation of UNSCR 2250 and 2419 in Nigeria. It aimed at exploring the components of the UNSCR 2250, 2419 and the connections with the Independent Progress Study on Youth and Peace and Security. It equipped and built the capacity of 70 youth and leaders of youth-led organizations with the necessary skills to effectively advocate and monitor the implementation of these resolutions.

The new Influencing Policy WG held its second meeting in June 2018. The Enabling Collaboration WG held two online meetings in May and June 2018, in which they discussed strategies and made work plans.

title.narrative: CSOs and GPPAC working group to develop a Community-Engagement Guideline on Peace for the UN

description.narrative: The Secretary-General’s 2018 report on Peacebuilding and Sustaining Peace requested the UN to develop UN system-wide guidelines for UN’s engagement with civil society. A working group is functioning since November 2018 consisting of various UN departments and GPPAC, along with two other civil society organizations. Through this working group, GPPAC supports the UN to develop a Community-Engagement Guidelines on Peacebuilding and Sustaining Peace as an overarching UN policy document.

title.narrative: After requests from youth members, the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs appointed an Ambassador for Youth and reached out to GPPAC in late June/early July 2019 to support its efforts to mainstream youth across the ministry.

description.narrative: The United Network of Young Peacebuilders, a GPPAC member and chair of the GPPAC YPS Working Group, has been advocating the Dutch MFA to embed the YPS agenda within the Ministry, by ensuring dedicated focal person and continued human resources to guide and monitor the implementation of UNSCR 2250. This has now been achieved with the appointment of the Ambassador for Youth. A Task Force was set up to support the temporary seat of the Netherlands in the Security Council, which also dealt with Youth, Peace, and Security (YPS) on an ad hoc basis.

title.narrative: The Women, Peace and Humanitarian Fund has selected GPPAC to become one of its four Civil Society Board members

description.narrative: The Women, Peace and Humanitarian Fund (WPHF) selected GPPAC to become one of its four Civil Society Board members. WPHF is a global partnership empowering local women to be a force for crisis response and lasting peace and was established in line with the Global Study on the Implementation of Security Council Resolution 1325 on Women and Peace and Security of the UN. Through a more active and leading role in WPHF, GPPAC can contribute directly to the shared goal of WPHF to bring about peaceful and gender equal societies. The GPPAC network - with around 200 civil society organisations world-wide as its members - can contribute to this goal with a conflict prevention and women’s human security perspective.

GPPAC also facilitated a group working on gendered indicators on prevention with the idea that they are tested later.

description.narrative: The Youth policy workshops brought together members from different GPPAC regions as well as external YPS experts. The participants not only learned about the youth policy but also about how the YPS agenda came about and why youth inclusion is important in peacebuilding. The workshops succeeded in engaging in intergenerational and inter-regional dialogues on the YPS agenda with GPPAC members and thus contribute to the implementation of the GPPAC youth policy.

title.narrative: Tunisian Network organized 8 political cafes.

description.narrative: The activity aims to create awareness about political participation and the need for youth and women to be involved in that process. Women and young people followed a training on the importance of the role they can play in their country, empowering them to become part of decision making and democratic processes in Tunisia such as voting during elections.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection

title.narrative: National Youth Camp for Peace 2020 in Cameroon

description.narrative: The activity was part of the localization of SDG16+ in Cameroon, it was organized under the theme “Building a Peaceful Youth for the Next Generation: A Youth Alternative Approach to SDG16+ Localization in Cameroon”. The youth camp brought together 100 participants representing different regions and communities of Cameroon with the objective of building peaceful, just and resilient youth leaders for the next generation. The youth camp for peace created safe spaces as well as offered the young people between the ages of 10-25 to learn and identify their roles in enhancing inclusive communities of peace. At the end of the National Youth Camp for Peace: • 100 young participants gained knowledge and skills on SDG16+, peace-building and non-violent techniques to conflict resolution • Transformation of youth mindsets to enhance the adoption of responsible behaviours and incline to attitudes that define them as peace ambassadors in their respective families and communities. • Capacities of the young girls and boys were improved to claim ownership of the Sustainable Development Goals particularly the peace goal, SDG16 • Participants committed individually and collectively to put knowledge and skills acquired into action as well as keep the youths connected.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: 1.2.2. Civil society reach out to key conflict/prevention stakeholders to engage them in developing inclusive prevention and protection strategies

title.narrative: The National Pre-transitional Committee (NPTC) renewed its commitment on the dissemination of the South Sudan peace agreement in June 2019, after the awareness raising workshop in collaboration with GPPAC member CEPO.

description.narrative: The commitment was renewed for the first time since they could not take any step in disseminating the agreement from the date of its signature (September 12, 2018). The NPTC is an institution created by the peace agreement to oversee the activities of the pre-interim period, convene a workshop on the development of key recommendations for the peace agreement principals, and launch the dissemination strategy which was funded by GPPAC with the contribution from CEPO. As a result of the advocacy training offered by GPPAC in 2018, GPPAC member CEPO (in Yei River State) was the first civil society organisation to lobby and influence the National Pre-transitional Committee (NPTC). The renewed commitment towards the implementation of the South Sudan peace deal builds hope and confidence in the population as a key step towards preventing the re-escalation of armed conflict in the country.

title.narrative: The GPPAC Peace Education Working Group co-hosted the 12th International Conference on Conflict Resolution Education, Bridging the divide in a Polarized Society at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, Ohio, USA, 22 – 26 May 2018

description.narrative: The conference brought together more than 200 educators, specialists, decision makers, etcetera among the 50 states and around the globe who have programs such as conflict management, human rights, peace education, democracy and civics education. Participants exchanged best practices, evaluation methodology, creation of policy implementation structures, consideration of obstacles to success, and new and innovative uses of training, resources, and technology.

title.narrative: Report on the ‘Educating for a Culture of Peace in Divided Societies: History, Dialogue, and Multiperspectivity Toward Reconciliation’ conference held by GPPAC’s Peace Education Working Group.

description.narrative: The conference convened educators from around the globe for a week-long, residential, learning community experience in Peace Education. A rich exchange of peacebuilding research, academic theory, best practices, and actions was shared with participants from around the world. As the report shows, the conference focused on global issues of particular relevance to Cyprus and the adjoining region of the Mediterranean, North Africa, Southern Europe, and the Middle East – the intersection of Asia, Africa and Europe. The conference emphasized the role of educators on all levels in addressing conflict in creative ways and offering alternatives to violence in contexts such as the Cypriot one. As the report shows, educating for practical and theoretical methods is of paramount importance for the creation of inclusive identities and a critical hope for the region, and for humanity as a whole.

description.narrative: The conference held on September 26-28, was used as an informational occasion for GPPAC members to participate in two television programs in order to explain to the general public the ambiguity of history and attitudes regarding the topic of the conference. title.narrative: On June 5th 2018 in Colombo, The Embassy of the Kingdom of The Netherlands in Sri Lanka together with GPPAC, organised in a first time collaboration, a Hague Talks event about the role of civil society in sustaining peace and preventing conflict

description.narrative: The event called “What’s the role of civil society in sustaining peace and preventing conflict?” brought together 85 participants representing local and international voices reflecting on the importance of civil society participation in preventing conflict and building peace. It was a first time collaboration that profited from the strengths of both GPPAC and the Dutch embassy in Sri Lanka. GPPAC has the connections to bring local and international civil society, while the embassy was able to effectively reach out to the Sri Lankan community.

title.narrative: Increased the visibility of four GPPAC members and of the GPPAC Secretariat in July 2019 during the Voices of SDG16+: Stories for Global Action event that was held at the High Level Political Forum in New York.

description.narrative: The event was launched by Saferworld, Transparency, Accountability, and Participation (TAP) Network, Conciliation Resources, Article 19, Peace Direct, Global Partnership for the Prevention of Armed Conflict (GPPAC), Civil Society Platform for Peacebuilding and Statebuilding (CSPPS), World Vision, Justice for All, Pax Christi, Life and Peace Institute, and Namati, with the support of the Swiss Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and the United Kingdom Department for International Development through the UN Development Programme’s Global Alliance.

title.narrative: GPPAC’s gender programme trained 17 experts in Women, Peace and Security (WPS) in policy, advocacy and communications during a Gender Experts Meeting in The Hague in April 2018

description.narrative: The experts were representing GPPAC Gender Focal Points and other GPPAC members from 10 GPPAC regions and 17 countries. According to evaluations, participants felt empowered after having been given the opportunity to share their experiences with other members; and increased their capacity and skills in lobbying and advocacy. As part of this, GPPAC organised an expert event, “We are not there yet: Women in conflict prevention and peacebuilding” together with the Knowledge Platform, on 18 April 2018. It facilitated a meaningful exchange between GPPAC’s gender experts and representatives of the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Dutch Civil Society on the implementation of Women Peace and Security Agenda. The Gender Experts Meeting was fully funded by GPPAC.

description.narrative: The first project is financed from the SP project’s “crisis intervention fund”: for Héritiers de la Justice (HJ) in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) around the delayed presidential election and prevention of electoral violence. HJ organised many public activities during autumn, including an impressive all-citizens strike in several Eastern cities and towns.

title.narrative: DD4 - 1.2. working together

description.narrative: 1.2.3. Civil society promotes, convenes or participates in inclusive multi-stakeholder dialogue processes and preventive and protective actions

title.narrative: Training on "Delta for Sustainable Communities" in Timor Leste

description.narrative: The general objective of the program is to raise critical consciousness of rural youth and their communities by supporting them to identify their common problems and undertake any actions to overcome those identified problems, particularly in relation to nexus of conflict drivers and ecological crisis especially in the time of COVID19. The ecological crisis has exacerbated conflict drivers, local people are suffering due to water scarcity and in some places causes horizontal conflict amongst communities. In light of this,GPPAC member the Peace Center-UNTL initiated the DELTA (Development, Education, and Leadership, Training in Action) as a method to engage all stakeholders in rural communities such as youth, students, women and local leaders to act towards sustainability. The program involves peace education and leadership trainings, seminars on ecological protection, and actual field work such as water conservation methods and tree planting.

description.narrative: The initiative was developed in Israel and occupied Palestine to provide a resource for teachers to train schoolchildren and their colleagues in Media Literacy - understanding the risks from media and how to counter them -, and in storytelling using mobile phones – part of the empowerment and understanding involved in media literacy. To develop awareness among children and teachers around the media – both its positive and its negative possibilities.

title.narrative: International feedback session and advocacy visit of young participants of the project “Cameras in Hands” took place in July 2019

description.narrative: The international advocacy engagement of Kyrgyzstani youth has been envisaged in the Project Document of “Cameras in Hands”. The project is a collaboration among the GPPAC Foundation, and GPPAC members Middle East Nonviolence and Democracy from Palestine and the Foundation for Tolerance International (FTI). FTI is GPPAC’s Regional Secretariat in Central Asia. The aim of the project is to foster the understanding between girls and boys of Kyrgyzstan from different gender, ethnic and social backgrounds, as well as give them a voice in local, national and international policy levels. In frames of this project, 8 chosen young project participants (15-17 years old) have come to The Hague, Utrecht, Amsterdam, and Brussels with the advocacy visit in order to present their movies created within the project and share the success stories of conflict prevention in action with the international community. They were accompanied by the project staff from our implementing partner, FTI, as well as the National Manager of United Nations Peacebuilding Support Office (UNPBSO) in Kyrgyzstan.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: The networks and network members build support for conflict prevention by engaging with and building capacities of key stakeholders

title.narrative: Strengthen local initiatives to prevent kidnappings and hostage-takings for ransom in the territory of Uvira in the DRC

description.narrative: The issue of kidnapping has been worsening and spreading to new areas. This issue is compounded by armed clashes that have resumed between Congolese ethnic militias which often cross over borders. To address the issue, GPPAC member in the DRC, Heritiers de la Justice, implemented a quick-impact project funded by GPPAC GS PuF Emergency Crisis Fund. The project was structured around three main activities: 1. The organisation of a brainstorming meeting on the issue of kidnapping and hostage-taking with government, civil society, police and media representatives. 2. provide populations with a toll-free number dedicated to answering related questions 3. produce and broadcast educational spots and awareness-raising messages on radio channels.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection

title.narrative: GPPAC’s Regional Network in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) ‘MENAPPAC’ created a network of youth peacebuilders (under the age of 27) on 27 April 2019

description.narrative: The network of youth peacebuilders aims to mainstream youth inclusivity within GPPAC’s regional network, and strengthen and unify youth voices on key political platforms. The network has representatives from Kuwait, Sudan, Syria, Iraq, Lebanon, Jordan and Egypt; and Palestinian Lebanese and Palestinian Syrians (refugees).

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection

title.narrative: Online trainings and webinars to face the challenges of conflict during the pandemic

description.narrative: The online training on "Analysis, Intervention and Dialogue: Making Sense of Conflict in the Age of Pandemic" was a three-session online based course given by GPPAC members 21, 22 and 23 of April with a duration of one hour and half, and it was attended by 100 participants. The second online training was on Human Security Basics: What Really Makes Us Secure When Confronting a Pandemic. It was a three-session Zoom based training facilitated by GPPAC Improving Practices Working Group Members and experts. It took place on 16, 17, 18 June. The duration of the training was 1.5 hours, and there were 90 participants.And last, the webinar: The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on human security in Georgia. It focused on the results of the field research done about the gender dimension of the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on human security in Georgia.

title.narrative: 1.1 Civil society capacity

description.narrative: 1.1.1. Network members engage in regional and cross-regional exchanges, working groups and action research on priority themes

title.narrative: UN offices and Member States have shown increased interest in Sustaining Peace expert-level roundtable series co-organised by GPPAC on July 2019

description.narrative: The roundtable did not exist before, and it now discusses pressing issues on implementing the sustaining the peace agenda among the UN, Member States, and civil society. The forum is now seen as a useful and trusted space to discuss challenging issues around Sustaining Peace. This includes a frank discussion on what is expected from the 2019 and 2020 Secretary-General reports on Sustaining Peace and Peacebuilding. It is also significant because this forum provides a space for civil society to directly influence key actors within the Sustaining Peace agenda and to raise issues and perspectives of their own in a context in which they are heard, as well as raise awareness about Sustaining Peace agenda in different forums.

title.narrative: 1.4. Acting on policies and operationalising norms

description.narrative: Governments and intergovernmental institutions take steps to act on policies and operationalise norms and frameworks for conflict prevention and the protection of people and collaborate with civil society

title.narrative: A webinar on ‘Women Engagement and Human Security in Georgia’ was hosted by Zaal Anjaparidze, GPPAC’s Regional Liaison Office for GPPAC South Caucasus, on 19 September 2019

description.narrative: The second webinar of GPPAC’s Improving Practice Webinar series focused on the engagement and empowerment of women promoting peace and confidence building in South Caucasus. Peacebuilder Nina Tsikhistavi-Khutsishvili, Director of the International Center on Conflict and Negotiation (ICCN) shared her experiences and challenges on the creation of the first ever Network of South Caucasus Women Mediators in the region. She was joined by Zaal Anjaparidze, GPPAC member and ICCN program coordinator. He shared his expertise on adaptive leadership pertinent to human security, how and whether it works in Georgia’s conflict zones and how it contributes to conflict prevention.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The statement was disseminated via the Global Secretariat and network members, also to media outlets.

description.narrative: 1.1.3. The networks produce relevant and timely lobby and advocacy statements, policy and position papers with civil society (conflict, context, thematic) analysis on target countries, situations and policies with particular attention to inclusivity.

title.narrative: On 20 September 2019, the Regional Intergovernmental Organizations (RIGOs) Steering Group members who organised the RIGOs conference that was co-organised by GPPAC, decided to convert the conference working group into a GPPAC RIGOs Working Group

description.narrative: The success of the RIGO conference changed the perception of the steering group. The members found that their advice and collaboration on this subject should go beyond just this one conference to sustained engagement on influencing/ interacting with regional actors.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: The networks and network members build support for conflict prevention by engaging with and building capacities of key stakeholders

title.narrative: Sam Risk from the United Nations Development Programme; and Henk Jan Brinkman, from the UN Peacebuilding Support Office (PBSO) recognized GPPAC’s success in co-organising the Regional Intergovernmental Organizations (RIGOs) conference, and agreed to join the GPPAC RIGOs Working Group on 20 September 2019.

description.narrative: The success of the RIGO conference lead to the addition of two high level political decision makers to the RIGOs Working Group.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

title.narrative: Training on mobile journalism

description.narrative: The training aimed to empower voices of educators and raise gender awareness. 12 stories and short films related to topics of gender, human rights, non-violence and school environment were produced. A presentation of the produced materials was organized in the presence of representatives of the Ministry of Education and was discussed. The Ministry requested that teachers transfer their experiences to some students and teach them to produce stories using the mobile phone. The project is implemented by GPPAC member Middle East Foundation for Democracy and Non-Violence.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: The networks and network members build support for conflict prevention by engaging with and building capacities of key stakeholders

title.narrative: Four out of sixteen GPPAC Eastern and Central African (ECA) Regional Steering Group members indicated in their evaluation forms (anonymous survey) that they had learnt and shifted their thinking from a purely conflict resolution preventive approach to one of peacebuilding and addressing conflicts; following a GPPAC training on Conflict Early Warning and Early Response in June 2019.

description.narrative: The training was organised by GPPAC-ECA from June 29-30 in Kampala, Uganda. It followed requests from members to enhance their skills in effectively responding to conflicts, transforming conflicts and building sustainable peace in their communities and the ECA region. The four members who indicated a shift of mindset also shared that they plan to integrate a preventive approach to conflict in the programmes of their organisations. This transformation leads to a collective approach of prioritising a preventive approach to violent conflict in the region.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection

title.narrative: Webinar on violent extremism and terrorism, Exploring New Frontiers in West Africa.

description.narrative: The webinar explored the dynamics of violent extremism in West Africa with focus on its impact on youth and the education systems and focused on how peace education could be used as a proactive and long-term strategy to address violent extremism. The activity raised awareness about the role of peace education to address violent extremism and contributed to knowledge sharing regarding human security and the implications for security policy development.

The webinar on Communication in Difficult Circumstances focused on sharing experiences of how communication processes and relations between teachers, students and parents are organised during the health crisis situation.

title.narrative: Webinar on lessons learned and how to replicate Participatory Video methodology

description.narrative: The webinar “The Participatory Video in Peacebuilding: Lessons Learnt from Occupied Palestinian Territories and Kyrgyzstan” focused on participatory video methodology and how this was used for peacebuilding in Palestine and Kyrgyzstan. Practical examples and lessons learned were shared. The webinar was joined by participants from: Kyrgyzstan, Palestine and The Hague. The discussion focused on the success of the project and how it could be replicated.

description.narrative: The willingness from these state institutions ushers on the window of opportunity for advocacy of ICCN’s developed CPToolbox.

title.narrative: The ‘Trauma Awareness, Resilience and Managing Stress’ module of the GPPAC Human Security Handbook was contextualized for Kenya

description.narrative: The ‘Trauma Awareness, Resilience and Managing Stress’ module of the GPPAC Human Security Handbook was contextualized by integrating regional issues, case studies and a more explicit gender lens, and further presented for input to a psychologist and counsellors conference in Nairobi (“Transformational Leadership through Solution Focused Model”) in collaboration with the International Leadership University (ILU) and the Council of Governors (CoG). The conference opened new partnership possibilities with some two County Governments on this topic.

The Iraqi army approached PPM to provide this second training, this time for higher-ranking officials, 25 generals. The Arabic translation of GPPAC’s Human security toolkit was used.

GPPACs work on gender equality and conflict prevention and revised Gender Policy have been presented for the first time in an Academic environment providing the opportunity for further connection with the University of Sapienza, other international civil society organisations as well as Italian CSOs working on Women, Peace and Security

title.narrative: In June-July 2019, ahead of and during the High Level Political Forum, three of the core SDG 16+ organisations, Saferworld, Transparency, Accountability, and Participation (TAP) Network, and Civil Society Platform for Peacebuilding and Statebuilding (CSPPS), together with GPPAC started to align their strategic messaging towards the need for greater localisation of the SDG 16+ agenda and supporting actors working on this

description.narrative: This is a result of fruitful and trusted partnership that has also showed strong alignment during the ‘Voices of SDG16+: Stories for Global Action’ event; previous exchange of knowledge and experiences with CSPPS about their involvement in Voluntary National Reviews in their member countries and several meetings in The Hague; GPPAC becoming a TAP Network partner; co-writing the Rome Declaration, and co-writing publications that were launched and disseminated at the side events during HLPF.
