title.narrative: GPPAC’s Enabling Collaboration Working Group’s secretariat, Initiatives for International Dialogue, published a news bulletin to cover the Government of the Republic of the Philippines (GRP) and the National Democratic Front of the Philippines (NDFP) peace process between Conflict and Peace Process between Aug-Sept 2019

description.narrative: This news bulletin covers the latest updates on the GRP-NDF peace process including the localisation of peace talks, red tagging of opposition leaders and the arrest of NDF political consultants. In this specific issue, it covered the effect of red tagging especially on the education sector as seen through the coverage of the suspension order of Lumad schools in Davao.

description.narrative: This outcome was the result of a policy dialogue between WANEP and ECOWAS ahead of an upcoming ECOWAS Summit. The dialogue was attended by representatives of 12 out of 16 ECOWAS ambassadors residents in Abuja, Nigeria. This outcome has direct bearing on the activities and GPPAC plans in West-Africa (PVE in Sahel) and of two of GPPAC’s global working groups on Preventing Violent Extremism and Influencing Policy. Document link: www.ecowas.int/ecowas-and-wanep-call-for-increased-synergy-in-order-to-prevent-violent-extremism-in-the-region/

description.narrative: This output came from GPPAC’s global Policy and Advocacy team participating actively in the Civil Society Platform for Peacebuilding and Statebuilding (CSPPS) Annual Core Group Meeting together with over 20 other civil society organisations working in peacebuilding and prevention. The meeting was held on 12-13 April 2018. The group was also hosted at GPPAC offices.

title.narrative: Exploring Conflict Prevention through Peace Education in Cameroon

description.narrative: This project focused on producing a video cartoon as an advocacy tool used by civil society organisations, institutions and individuals to promote peace education at local and national levels. The cartoon play is available in English, French and Pidgin English. The initiative was complemented with a two day workshop with heads of secondary schools, primary schools and officials from the ministries of basic, secondary and higher education on peace education. The project delivered knowledge and skills to heads of schools to enhance peace education; and children were introduced to the culture of peace concept, non-violent communication and learned alternatives to violence

And GPPAC freelance press officers in Georgia published 2 articles on peace and conflict prevention: http://www.resonancedaily.com/index.php?id_rub=2&id_artc=97399 (Conflict prevention architecture) http://www.resonancedaily.com/index.php?id_rub=2&id_artc=97400 (The importance of an archive on conflict resolution)

description.narrative: Three thematic meetings with youth groups resulted in two policy briefs: "Role of history as an instrument in the eruption and development of the armed conflicts in Georgia"; and "Qualitative analysis of the sense of citizenship among the Abkhazia-based youth amid COVID-19 pandemic".

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: 1.2.2. Civil society reach out to key conflict/prevention stakeholders to engage them in developing inclusive prevention and protection strategies

title.narrative: GPPAC’s Peace Education Working Group produced a case study on Armenia’s Peace and Conflict Resolution Education in Schools Program

description.narrative: Through a series of case studies, the GPPAC Peace Education Working Group highlights examples of how peace and conflict education efforts are being scaled in countries and regions, both within the formal education structures (schools, teacher training facilities) for primary, secondary and higher education, as well as in the community. Each case study highlights the efforts that civil society and government actors have undertaken in order to create collaborative processes to develop, disseminate, train, monitor and improve the learning and application of Peace Education. The case studies also highlight lessons learned to assist those who are seeking to engage with civil society and government actors to improve peace and conflict education initiatives in their own countries and regions. The first case studies of the series is 'Armenia’s Peace & Conflict Resolution Education in Schools Program'.

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection

title.narrative: Actors use “Strategic framework for the development of civil peacebuilding activities in Ukraine”

description.narrative: Throughout 2017, GPPAC members in Eastern Europe continued to advocate for the “Strategic framework for the development of civil peacebuilding activities in Ukraine” among various stakeholders, as well as to integrate some of the approaches from the document during the development of action plans of other agencies and organisations. Two practical outcomes of this work include, firstly, the fact that the “Strategic framework” helped in developing potential impact criteria for a long-term project, which is to be implemented by a platform of 5 Ukrainian and 1 international organisation during 2018-2020. Secondly, the fact that materials from the “Strategic framework” were used in developing input for the strategic planning of the activities of the “Renaissance” Foundation (the Ukrainian branch of the G. Soros foundation).

description.narrative: 1.2.2 Civil society reach out to key conflict/prevention stakeholders to engage them on developing inclusive prevention and protection strategies

title.narrative: Training for East-Central African CSOs and civil-military actors in Kampala, Uganda

description.narrative: Together with IPSTC, a mapping of potential training providers in the East and Central African region has been made in order to introduce the GPPAC Handbook on Human Security and regional civil society experts as resources for integrated (multi-stakeholder) training at regional level. GPPAC and County Governance Watch from Kenya organised a training for East-Central African members and other civ-mil actors in September in Kampala, Uganda. The training coincided with the RSG for GPPAC East-Central Africa where the strategic directions were set for 2017-2019.

title.narrative: DD5 - 1.2 - Working together

description.narrative: 1.2.1. Civil society initiates or participates in joint capacity development with state actors on how to work together and operationalise inclusive prevention and protection mechanisms and norms (including security sector training, briefings on the role of civil society, trainings on norms)

title.narrative: Training of Trainers on Preventing Violent Extremism in the Sahel and Nigeria

description.narrative: Training of Trainers workshops on the “Teaching Manual for the Prevention of Violent Extremism in Sahel and Nigeria” were organized in August and September 2020 in Niger, Mali, Burkina Faso and Nigeria. 60 teachers (15 x 4) were trained on Preventing Violent Extremism to enable them to build resilience of school children to help prevent violent extremism in the Sahel. Also in attendance were local authorities, traditional leaders as well as representatives of Intergovernmental and international organisations. The PVE manual seeks to complement regional efforts in grooming a new generation of resilient young people equipped and prepared to prevent violent extremism in the Sahel and Nigeria. All the stakeholders expressed their entire support for effective implementation of the project.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: 1.2.2. Civil society reach out to key conflict/prevention stakeholders to engage them in developing inclusive prevention and protection strategies

title.narrative: For the first time, 11 CSOs joined forces between February and July 2019, for the advocacy around SDG16+ through an innovative campaign “Voices for SDG 16+: Stories of Global Action” that shifted from single advocacy as individual organisations towards joint advocacy messages and joint advocacy events in Rome in May 2019 and in NY in July 2019 at the High Level Political Forum (HLPF) on SDGs to argue for greater focus on further local implementation of SDG 16+

description.narrative: Voices of SDG16+: Stories of Global Action is a collaborative campaign to bring the work of civil society on SDG16+ to the 2019 High Level Political Forum (HLPF) on SDGs. Individuals and organisations from around the world had the opportunity to submit short videos telling their “stories” of best practices towards SDG16+ at the national and local levels. The campaign provided a unique opportunity to showcase their stories – featuring both challenges and successes – and their concrete commitments to advancing SDG16+. Until 2019 and the HLPF, SDG 16 and its peace related goals had not been received broad attention and organisations working in the field of peace had undertaken individual advocacy but this had not translated into a joint endeavour. The fact that 11 organisations coalesced around the campaign, agreed to pool resources and developed joint advocacy messages and events is significant as it is an important qualitative shift in the way policy and implementing organisations have been working. It is equally significant since the joint advocacy increases the likelihood of its messages being taken up. GPPAC helped shape the form and content of the campaign as one of its earliest partners, it mobilised its members to submit videos (5 videos of members were submitted), participated in the selection of the videos, bringing the winners to New York as well as co-organising the events in New York and covering the campaign through its social media outlets. The video of GPPAC member, Women in Alternative Action (WAA) Cameroon Out of these 150 videos 13 winners were selected, which were then invited to come to the HLPF. The video of GPPAC member, Women in Alternative Action (WAA) Cameroon was one of 13 winners.

title.narrative: Outcome 1.2 - Working together (DD4)

A broad spectrum of civil society, governmental and intergovernmental actors in Ghana identified synergies in their work around SDG 16+ and potential avenues for collaboration, as a result of the June 2019 SDG validation workshop, held in Accra by GPPAC’s Regional Secretariat for West Africa, West Africa Network for Peacebuilding (WANEP), in collaboration with GPPAC.

description.narrative: WANEP held a validation workshop ‘National Reviews on the Progress in SDG 16+ Implementation in Ghana and the Role of CSOs’ on 11 June, in Accra. The workshop was an important moment for key stakeholders to engage around SDG 16+’s implementation and present the key findings and recommendations of WANEP Ghana’s research. GPPAC shared the experience and lessons learned from SDGs Voluntary National Review in Cameroon. One of the workshop’s conclusions was to link SDG16 with other SDGs, and invest in adequate infrastructures, including infrastructures for peace (such as the National Peace Council in Ghana) and access to justice in a coherent and integrated manner to contribute to sustainable development and peace in Ghana.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: The networks and network members build support for conflict prevention by engaging with and building capacities of key stakeholders

title.narrative: SDG16+ Toolkit developed to for CSOs implementation at local level

description.narrative: We developed the SDG16 Toolkit to respond to the members’ question: “how can we use SDG 16 for our daily work?”. The SDG16 Toolkit guides to useful material, experiences and suggestions about the local implementation of SDG16+. In responding to 20 questions, its responses includes information on: governmental SDGs focal points in various countries, how the SDG 16 review process looks like, developing advocacy strategies and how to take part in decision-making processes around SDGs. It also provides users with recommendations on how to influence key actors for SDG16+ related implementation or how to write a shadow civil society review on SDG 16+.

title.narrative: 1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection

title.narrative: After long-standing hesitations, civil society actors and other non-traditional peace actors (academia, religious sector) have expressed desire and commitment to create spaces for regular and deeper civil society coordination in engaging the Government of the Republic Philippines (GRP) and the National Democratic Front (NDF) peace process, particularly EO70 (GRP’s supposed Whole-of-Society Approach) and the localised peace talks. Moreover, GPPAC’s Regional Secretariat in South East Asia, Initiatives for International Dialogue, and Balay Minadaw were identified as facilitators; which happened during the Winning the Peace Conversation in April 2019.

description.narrative: Winning the Peace Conversation is the biggest gathering of multi-stakeholders to engage with the Government of the Republic Philippines, the National Democratic Front peace process, and the new Secretary of the Office of the Presidential Advisor on the Peace Process (OPAPP). There has been a long-standing hesitance among peace advocates/NGOs to deepen collaboration and joint action as well as hesitance among other sectors (private sector, academia, religious sector, etc) to be further involved in the GRP-NDFP peace process. This expression of commitment builds on the GPPAC Enabling Collaboration Working Group and the Secretariat’s objective to broaden the constituency of the GRP-NDFP, and to develop trust and coordination between the actors already engaged with the peace process. Moreover, during the meeting, they expressed the need to start the process of developing a National People’s Peace Agenda.

title.narrative: 1.2. Working together

description.narrative: The networks and network members build support for conflict prevention by engaging with and building capacities of key stakeholders

title.narrative: On 12 March 2019, during the Commission on the Status of Women 63, the Youth, Peace, and Security Advisor to UN Women requested the representative of GPPAC’s Youth, Peace, and Security Working Group to have the copy of her contribution on the panel as it showed the link between access to social protection, public infrastructure and conflict prevention.

description.narrative: Youth, Peace, and Security Advisor to UN Women recognised the link, which was not made clear before, and acknowledged the contribution of the United Network of Young Peacebuilders and GPPAC to it. Understanding the link contributes to the understanding of the unique challenges that young women face. GPPAC has contributed through the presentation of Eliska Jelinkova, the Co-Chair of the GPPAC Youth, Peace, and Security Working Group during the panel “Sustainable Infrastructure for Gender Equality: Putting Prevention Up Front”. The panel was organised by GPPAC in cooperation with ICRtoP and Friedrich Ebert Stiftung, showing that gender equality is linked to inclusive human security, and when women and girls are empowered and have access to the services they need, states are more peaceful and communities are safer.

title.narrative: 1.3. Improving policy and adopting recommendations

title.narrative: Increased ability of the GPPAC South Caucasus regional network members to respond to the crisis resulting in a joint statement with regard to the resumed Armenian-Azerbaijani hostilities in September 2020

description.narrative: n September 2020, the members of GPPAC South Caucasus regional network have increased their preparedness to respond promptly to the Armenian-Azerbaijani armed conflict and demonstrated increased solidarity towards its resolution which resulted in the joint statement. The outcome is important due to a very tense situation in the region, especially when it comes to the differences in the attitudes of the civil society from Armenia and Azerbaijan to the conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh. The fact that it was possible for both sides to agree on the joint statement is an important and significant change. See statement here: https://gppac.net/news/gppac-calls-governments-armenia-and-azerbaijan-immediately-call-ceasefire

description.narrative: 1.2.2. Civil society reach out to key conflict/prevention stakeholders to engage them in developing inclusive prevention and protection strategies

title.narrative: First on-line meeting of the Global Working Group on Prevention of Violent Extremism (PVE)

description.narrative: • GPPAC and RCSS from Sri Lanka (Regional Secretariat of GPPAC South Asia) started the thematic Working Group on Prevention of Violent Extremism (PVE) with a first online meeting in September. Apart from exchanging experiences, the Working Group will formulate a position paper for the upcoming ISG meeting and recommend what GPPAC should do (further) with the topic.

title.narrative: 1.1 - Civil society capacity

description.narrative: 1.1.4. Network members work together to inform, monitor and contribute to implementing prevention and protection strategies (incl WPS, PVE..)

title.narrative: Three one-pagers were created to highlight the Strategic Partnership’s work in Mali, Philippines and Kenya which the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs sent to its regional desks and embassies.
1.1. Civil society capacity

description.narrative: The networks and its members enhance, document and disseminate civil society expertise and skills for inclusive prevention and protection
